{{cleanup|reason=tone, flow|date=July 2018}} [[File:CRPE logo.png|alt=Logo of CRPE|thumb|294x294px|CRPE's logo.<ref name="CRPE-EJ.org/About" />]] The '''Center on Race, Poverty & the Environment''' (CRPE) is a California-based [[environmental justice]] organization founded in 1989 dedicated to providing legal aid to [[grassroots organization]]s in environmental justice communities. CRPE helps communities dealing with problems related to the disproportionate burden of pollution placed upon poor people and people of color. CRPE’s mission is “to achieve environmental justice and healthy, sustainable communities through collective action and the law”.<ref name="CRPE-EJ.org/About" /> As part of this mission, CRPE provides organizational, technical, and legal assistance to help underserved communities stop immediate environmental threats. With their main offices located in San Francisco and [[Delano, California|Delano, CA]], they conduct most of their efforts in Central California, especially the [[San Joaquin Valley]], which includes Delano and [[Kern County, California|Kern County]], but they also work across the United States.<ref name="CRPE-EJ.org/About" />
==History of CRPE== [[File:California map showing Kern County.png|alt=A map of California highlighting Kern County.|thumb|A map of California highlighting Kern County, which is part of the San Joaquin Valley and home to the cities of Delano, Bakersfield, and Shafter, places where CRPE has conducted a lot of their work. Delano is also home to one of CRPE's headquarters.<ref name="CRPE-EJ.org/About" />]]The two founders of CRPE, [[Luke Cole]] and [https://crpe-ej.org/about/ Ralph Abascal], created the organization in 1989. In order to help the environmental justice movement, Cole continued to push the philosophy of a “from the ground up” framework. This ultimately means that the [https://crpe-ej.org/about/ CRPE] works to establish a foundation that is community based in which it focuses on organizing directly through the members of society that are impacted by environmental justice issues. It focuses on three objectives; "(1) to build individual capacity; (2) increase community power vis-a-vis decision-makers; and (3) address environmental hazards facing the community."<ref>{{cite web |title=Center on Race, Poverty & the Environment |url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/05-0557231 |website=GuideStar |publisher=GuideStar |accessdate=28 September 2018}}</ref> Abascal was an attorney for over 29 years and was dedicated to helping clients of various environmental justice topics and also worked to educate others on [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]] advocacy. There are numerous locations that CRPE focuses their work, but most of their efforts are rooted in California, specifically in the San Joaquin Valley and Kern County, which includes the city of Delano, home to many CRPE efforts. CRPE has offices in San Francisco and Delano, CA.<ref name="CRPE-EJ.org/About" /> CRPE has also conducted work in Alaska.<ref name="Bauman 2008" />
==Notable People of CRPE==
The Center on Race, Poverty and the Environment operates with the help of environmental justice attorneys and lawyers. Co-founder Luke Cole provided legal and technical assistance to attorneys and community groups involved in environmental justice struggles nationwide. Berkeley’s [[Ecology Law Quarterly]] awarded him with the Environmental Leadership Award in 1997. Ingrid Brostrom and Caroline Farrell are also noteworthy people associated with CRPE and the legal side of environmental justice. Brostrom is an attorney and Assistant Director at CRPE who focuses on helping low-income communities that are disproportionately faced with environmental injustices.<ref name="Auperlee 2007"/> Farrell is the Executive Director at CRPE and based out of the Delano office. She advocates for communities of color as well as low-income communities by leading many different environmental justice groups. She is known to be a major leader in environmental advocacy in the Valley.<ref name="London et al. 2011" />
==CRPE's Work==
CRPE participates in many campaigns and legal disputes to support the health and rights of underrepresented communities and communities of color who struggle under the burdens of environmental injustices. This organization works to provide solutions for the communities for both environmental and health issues. CRPE uses integrated legal techniques to work towards the goals of environmental justice groups that they are working with.<ref name="Foster and Glick 2007"/>
===Climate Change and Energy===
The Romo v. Brown<ref>Romo vs. Brown (2017, February 11). https://crpe-ej.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Romo-v-Brown-Complaint-Endorsed-By-Court.pdf</ref> is one of CRPE’s major open legal cases that surrounds climate change and energy issues. This case involves Governor Jerry Brown’s decision to sign the Senate Bill No. 4, ending regulation on hydraulic fracturing, also known as [[Hydraulic fracturing|fracking]]. Fracking is a process that extracts natural gas from reservoirs beneath the surface by spraying large amounts of water mixed with sand and chemicals into the rock to break it.<ref name="Rowe 2016" /> On Nov 9th 2015 the Kern County Board of Supervisors passed an amendment, which allowed oil & gas zoning permits to be obtained quickly and without the public’s knowledge through public hearings. These two issues caused Rodrigo Romo to sue the Governor and the Division of Oil, Gas & Geothermal Resources due to various health issues his daughters face. Other community members were also upset, and went on a 4-day fast (known as the Cruz Fasts) to protest the amendment and Senate Bill. These actions from the community members attempted to end fracking and other oil extraction methods. All the chemicals produced throughout the fracking process releases high amounts of pollutants into the air, including methane, benzene, nitrogen oxides (NOx), and hydrogen sulfide. These pollutants destroy the ozone layer, leaving Kern County third in most ozone pollution. This could potentially lead to many negative health effects from high level of particulate matter.<ref name="Rowe 2016" /> CRPE also represented the residents of [[Kettleman City, California|Kettleman City]], another area in the San Joaquin Valley that is exposed to environmental hazards due to growing industrial demands. Oil and gas production have exposed this small town and its community members to various chemical hazards. One of the largest waste facilities in the region is only 3 miles from the city.<ref name="Richter 2017" />
In another legal battle, CRPE represented the [[Iñupiat|Inupiat]] town of [[Kivalina, Alaska|Kivalina]] as they sued Exxonmobil in the case of [[Kivalina v. ExxonMobil Corp.|Kivalina vs Exxonmobil Corp.]] for contributing to [[climate change]]. Kivalina is located on an island which was protected from erosion by winter freezing however, as the arctic gets warmer, this ice is no longer protecting the island’s shores from erosion. With the help of CRPE, they took this case to federal court, demanding that these companies pay for their relocation as their island shrunk. This was a historic case that set the tone for the use of common law in the fight against large corporations in the battle against climate change. They ultimately lost the suit.<ref name="Péloffy 2013" /><ref name="Schwartz 2010" />
===Sustainable Agriculture===
CRPE sued multiple dairies in the San Joaquin valley over their noncompliance with [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|US Environmental Protection Agency]] regulations. They allied with other groups to address harmful methane emissions produced by these farms. One farm was building a facility that would house more cows than allowed under the EPA regulations. This dairy asserted that they would only house the number of cows allowed under EPA regulations, and that they would never use the facility to its full capacity. CRPE sued under the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Clean Air Act]], arguing that the dairy’s claims differed from their actions.<ref name="Ruby 2005" /><ref name="Gustin 2016" />
CRPE wrote a report about the institutional failures of the EPA, with regard to specific cases concerning agricultural justice in California. In the report, CRPE states that the EPA denied [[Socioeconomics|socioeconomically]] underserved communities in California’s agricultural centers appropriate protection from pesticide exposure, including areas where schoolchildren were affected. This reported include claims regarding improper administration of Title VI of the [[Civil Rights Act]].<ref name="Lopez-Wagner 2016" />
CRPE in conjunction with the [[Center for Environmental Health]] (CEH) worked on a lawsuit against [[Dow Chemical Company]] for the use of [[1,3-Dichloropropene|Telone]], a pesticide that they have found often impacts Latino communities. CRPE and CEH, base their case in the [http://cehtp.org/file/pesticides_schools_report_april2014_pdf findings] by the [[California Department of Public Health|California Department of Health]] that Latino school aged children are significantly more likely to be exposed to the highest levels of toxic pesticides such as Telone. CRPE stated claims that the state had ignored the threats that their chemicals posed to the health of local schools and communities. In their legal action, CRPE called for an end of fumigation and high levels of pesticide use in these California communities. <ref>{{cite web |title=CEH Taking on a Notorious Chemical Polluter |url=https://www.ceh.org/news-events/newsletters/content/october2016/ |website=October 2016 News Letter |publisher=Center for Environmental Health |accessdate=29 September 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news |last1=Barboza |first1=Tony |title=Pesticide use near schools triggers a push for statewide regulations |url=http://www.latimes.com/science/la-me-adv-pesticides-schools-20150614-story.html# |accessdate=29 September 2018 |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=June 13, 2015}}</ref>
===Toxics in Our Environment===
Air pollution is a large source of environmental distress in the San Joaquin Valley, a central point of most work done by CRPE. Air pollution has been connected to public health problems, such as [[asthma]] and [[cancer]]. In one study, researchers determined that air quality in the very polluted San Joaquin Valley, a socioeconomically underserved region, may contribute to the development of congenital conditions in marginalized communities.<ref name="Padula 2013" /> This air pollution affects many communities that CRPE represents as part of their work called “Toxics in our Environment”.
In one case taken on by CRPE, the California Portland Cement Company was burning tires in Kern County, and releasing highly toxic chemicals into the surrounding atmosphere. The public protested against this pollution, but California Portland and the Kern County Air Pollution Control District did not respond to concerns and challenged any presented lawsuits. CRPE represented the Kern County community members in opposition of California Portland and the Air District to help reduce toxins in the environment of this central California community.<ref name="Kuhn 1999" />
In another case, CRPE vs. San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District, CRPE sued the Air District, a government organization committed to protecting air quality in San Joaquin, for failing to meet air quality standards for [[ozone]] set by the Clean Air Act for three consecutive years. The ozone problem has prevented the San Joaquin Valley, a region home to many Hispanic/Latinx farmworkers, from having healthy air since the 1970s, mostly due to the Air District’s inability to implement ozone pollution control measures that would reduce ozone emissions by regulating emissions of [[Volatile organic compound|VOCs]] and [[NOx]], ozone creating chemicals. Eventually, the Air District settled the lawsuit, promising to implement the measures. Since the case was settled, the amount of ozone in the community has been reduced.<ref name="Yengoyan 2003" />
In a more remote case, CRPE joined with other groups to represent the town of Kivalina in Alaska, as they fought to hold [[Red Dog mine]] accountable for illegal pollution of waterways with mining waste and debris. The EPA listed the Red Dog mine as the top source of toxic emissions in the country, and it is the largest zinc mine in the world.<ref name="Bauman 2008" /> Kivalina is a small Inupiat town, where the nearby mine’s pollution contaminated fish and other animals needed for Kivalina’s subsistence. Kivalina claims that Red Dog has violated its permit over 4,000 times. Represented by CRPE, Kivalina sued [[Teck Cominco]], the mine’s parent company. Teck Cominco claimed that the rivers have been made cleaner by the mining, along with the removal of zinc. They also asserted that their failure to meet permit requirements is due to Kivalina blocking their efforts to renew their permit.<ref name="Stano 2014" /><ref name="Bauman 2008" />
===Community Investment and Infrastructure===
The Delano Guardians Committee represents members of Kern County in the decision making processes within the city council.<ref name="Sierra Health Foundation 2017" /> In a lawsuit between the city of Delano and the Delano Guardians Committee, the Delano Guardians sued the city over rising utility rates. The lawsuit claimed that by facilitating these increases the city violated policies that state a majority of voters must approve property-related fees.<ref name="KGET 2013" /> CRPE helped the Delano Guardians and people of Delano fight the city by providing them with legal aid and representation.
CRPE has also worked with the Comite Progreso de Lamont, a group of community members working towards improving the lives of the citizens of Lamont in Kern County. Through their joint efforts they succeeded in their east side sidewalks project. This project will create sidewalks in an area where numerous accidents have occurred.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/new-sidewalks-in-lamont-bring-safety-to-kids-and-drivers|title=New sidewalks in Lamont bring safety to kids and drivers|last=News|first=Emma Goss, Eyewitness|work=KBAK|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
Additionally, CRPE, along with The Power to the People Campaign, has worked with Kern County community members to help define and establish guidelines for a healthy community. The guidelines are as follows:
# Promotion of Environmental Health and Justice # Economic Opportunity for All People # Equity and Justice in Green Jobs<ref name="CRPE Green Paper" />
Through these guidelines, and their community investments, CRPE aims to build and protect the communities of Kern County. Citizens face many issues, including unemployment rates as high as 9.9%, which often disproportionately affect the large Hispanic population within the county.<ref name="Sierra Health Foundation 2017" /> While these guidelines were created to help the citizens Kern County, it is hoped that they can also be implemented in the other counties that comprise the San Joaquin Valley.
===Movement Building===
CRPE supports the missions of many grassroots organizations in the San Joaquin Valley and often partners with one or more groups at a time to help improve a community’s wellbeing and environment.<ref name="CRPE-EJ.org/About" /> In doing so, the CRPE demonstrates organizational integration, which involves lawyers merging their work with the goals of environmental justice groups or organizations they work with.<ref name="Foster and Glick 2007" /> Some of CRPE’s partners include: the Committee for a Better [[Arvin, California|Arvin]], the Committee for a Better [[Shafter, California|Shafter]], Delano Guardians, [[Greenfield, California|Greenfield]] Walking Group, and Comite Progreso de [[Lamont, California|Lamont]]. The Committee for a Better Arvin, with the help of CRPE, strives to obtain better water and air quality for marginalized communities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://airhugger.wordpress.com/tag/committee-for-a-better-arvin/|title=Committee for a Better Arvin|last=|first=|date=|website=airhugger.wordpress.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The Committee for a Better Shafter currently receives help from CRPE in the Romo Case concerning fracking and energy issues in their low income town.<ref name="Rowe 2016" /> CRPE helped Delano Guardians sue the city of Delano over unfair spikes in utility costs that highly impacted the low income community.<ref name="KGET 2013" /> The Greenfield Walking Group and CRPE teamed up to create a walkability assessment that led to the clean up of Greenfield, CA parks with the goal of making the mainly Latinx/Hispanic community safer and healthier by picking up litter, refurbishing paths, and implementing measures aimed at reducing gang presence in the parks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://californiawalks.org/greenfield-walking-group/|title=Greenfield Walking Group|last=|first=|date=|website=CaliforniaWalks.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> CRPE and the Comite Progreso de Lamont work to promote a clean environment and better community for health and education in Lamont, CA, a low income community of color burdened by many environmental issues, especially air pollution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bearmtnprk.com/files/828842eef/Minutes+January+18%2C+2018.pdf|title=Minutes January 18, 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=January 18, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=April 22, 2018}}</ref> All of these partnerships involve CRPE providing legal aid and support to grassroots organizations in order to improve underserved communities.
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="CRPE-EJ.org/About">{{cite web|title= About The Center on Race, Poverty, and the Environment|website=The Center on Race, Poverty, and the Environment|accessdate=20 April 2018|url=https://crpe-ej.org/about/}}</ref> <ref name="Auperlee 2007">Aupperlee, A. “Hinkley files suit against county”. Daily Press - Victorville, CA. (2007).</ref> <ref name="Foster and Glick 2007">Foster, S., & Glick, B. “Integrative Lawyering: Navigating the Political Economy of Urban Redevelopment”. California Law Review, Inc., 95(5), 1999-2072. (2007).</ref> <ref name="Rowe 2016">Rowe, Allison. “Kern County, California: Where Big Oil, dirty air, and a tenacious community converge”. Williams College Archives (2016). https://sites.williams.edu/envi-322-s16/category/ca-by-allie-rowe/</ref> <ref name="Richter 2017">Richter, Lauren. “Constructing insignificance: critical race perspectives on institutional failure in environmental justice communities”. Environmental Sociology, (2017), DOI: 10.1080/23251042.2017.1410988</ref> <ref name="Péloffy 2013">Péloffy, Karine. “Kivalina vs. Exxonmobil: A Comparative Case Comment.” McGill International Jornal of Sustainable Development Law and Policy 9 (2013): 119.</ref> <ref name="Schwartz 2010">Schwartz, John. “Courts as Battlefields in Climate Fights.” The New York Times (2010).</ref> <ref name="Ruby 2005">Ruby, Sarah. The '''Chaush''' ({{lang-ur|{{nq|چاوش}}}}) are [[Muslim]]<ref name="Mediaeval Deccan history">Mediaeval Deccan History, eds Kulkarni, M A Naeem and de Souza, Popular Prakashan, Bombay, 1996, pg 63, https://books.google.com/books?id=O_WNqSH4ByQC&lpg=PA52&pg=PA63#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref> community of [[Hadhrami people|Hadhrami]] [[Arab]] descent found in the [[Deccan Plateau|Deccan]] region of [[India]].<ref name="Khalidi">Omar Khalidi, [https://books.google.com/books?id=O_WNqSH4ByQC&lpg=PA52&pg=PA63#v=onepage&q&f=false The Arabs of Hadramawt in Hyderabad] in Mediaeval Deccan History, eds Kulkarni, Naeem and de Souza, Popular Prakashan, Bombay, 1996, pg 63</ref> The name is believed to originate from the [[Turkish language|Turkish]] word [[Chiaus]] used during the [[Ottoman era]] of the [[Balkans]] for military officers who were often tasked with guarding palaces.<ref name="Mediaeval Deccan history"/> They have a common origin with the [[Arab (Gujarat)|Chavuse]] community of [[Gujarat]].
The Chaush were brought from Yemen to work in the former [[Hyderabad State]] as military men and body guards for the '''[[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam]]s'''. It is said that especially when it came to safe guarding his family, the [[Mir Osman Ali Khan|7th Nizam]] had absolute trust on these Arab bodyguards. <ref name="TheHindu">[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-downtown/a-home-for-the-chaush-community/article2483556.ece A home for the Chaush community], [[The Hindu]], 25 Sep 2011</ref> They are most concentrated in the neighbourhood of [[Barkas, Hyderabad|Barkas]] in [[Hyderabad]] city.<ref name="TheHindu" /> Many Chaush later settled in other parts of India, and around the world as part of the Hyderabadi diaspora, especially in Pakistan, and [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]].
The founders of both the [[Qu'aiti]] and [[Kathiri]] states in [[Hadhramawt]] had previously served as [[jemadar]]s in [[Hyderabad]].<ref>Boxberger, Linda. On the Edge of Empire: Hadhramawt, Emigration, and the Indian Ocean, 1880s-1930s. 2002. [[State University of New York Press ]]</ref>
Among the best known cultural contributions of the Chaush to India are [[Marfa (music)|Marfa]] music and dance, and [[Hyderabadi haleem]], both which are culturally important to the [[Hyderabadi Muslims|Hyderbadi Muslim people]], and seen at almost all wedding ceremonies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/from-the-era-of-the-nizams-arabi-marfa-continues-to-be-a-hit-even-now/article4032031.ece|title=From the era of the Nizams ‘Arabi marfa’ continues to be a hit even now|date=2012-10-26|newspaper=The Hindu|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
==Chaush people== * [[Subhani ba Yunus]], Pakistani actor * [[General El Edroos]] * [[Sulaiman Areeb]], Urdu poet * [[Awaz Sayeed]], Urdu writer
==See also== * [[Arab (Gujarat)|Arabs of Gujarat]] * [[Hadhrami people]] * [[Siddi]] * [[Hyderabadi Pahalwan]] * [[Chiaus]]

Abaidoo |location = [[Kumasi]], [[Sunyani]] {{flag|Ghana}} |faculty = 90 |students = 2,063 |colours = Green and White {{color box|Green}}{{color box|white}} |website = http://canr.knust.edu.gh/ }}
The '''College of Agriculture and Renewable Natural Resources''' (CANR) is one of the six Colleges of today’s [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]]. It was formed in January 2005 following the promulgation of the revised University statuses in December 2004. It emerged from the former Faculty of Agriculture, the Institute of Renewable Natural Resources and the School of Forestry. The College has a total of 13 academic departments with a student population of approximately 2000 and an academic staff strength of about 90, and 130 supporting staff.<ref name="KNUST_CANR_About">{{cite web |url=http://canr.knust.edu.gh/aboutus.php |title=College of Agricultural and Renewable Natural Resources: About Us |accessdate=2009-10-29 |work=About Us |publisher=Kwame Nkrumah University of Science And Technology }}</ref>
== About the College == The College of Agriculture and Natural Resources was established in January 2005, following the promulgation of the revised University statutes in December 2004. It was formed from the former Faculty of Agriculture, the Institute of Renewable Natural Resources and the School of Forestry, Sunyani. The College is mandated to train and equip graduates with the requisite academic and entrepreneurial skills in the areas of agricultural production and natural resource management for sustainable national development, in addition to carrying out research and extension services in these areas.
The College of Agriculture and Natural Resources is one of the six Colleges of the University, with a mandate to train, research and disseminate knowledge in sustainable agriculture, renewable natural resources management and rural development.
== Academics == The College offers a variety of programmes for both undergraduate and graduate studies. Programmes are regularly reviewed while new programmes are so structured to ensure ready job market for our graduates. Quality training which blends theory with practicals prepare students to face real world situation and also offer practical solution to problems.
The College is involved in a number of collaborative researches with National and International Institutions and Organizations such as FORIG, MOFA, Forestry Commission, ICRA, and CIDA among others.
=== Faculties & Departments <ref name="KNUST_VCs_Report_2009">{{Citation |title = The Vice-chancellor's Report |publisher=University Press - KNUST |location=Kumasi |date=June 2009 }}</ref> === Located at the west end of the University campus, CANR houses three Faculties:
==== Faculty of Agriculture ==== * Department of Agricultural Economics, Agribusiness and Extension * Department of Animal Science * Department of Crop and Soil Sciences * Department of Horticulture
==== Faculty of Forest Resources Technology ==== * Department of Social Forestry * Department of Land Rehabilitation and Reclamation * Department of Ecotourism * Department of Wood Processing and Marketing.
==== Faculty of Renewable Natural Resources ==== * Department of Agroforestry * Department of Fisheries and Watershed Management * Department of Silviculture and Forest Management * Department of Wildlife and Range Management * Department of Wood Science and Technology
=== Research Centres === In addition to the Faculties, CANR has four(4) Research Centres: * Bureau of Integrated Rural Development(BIRD). * Centre for Biodiversity Utilisation and Development(CBUD). * Dairy/Beef cattle Research Station, Boadi. * Agriculture Research Station, Anwomaso.
=== Programmes<ref>{{cite book|title=Student's Guide|year=2010|publisher=University Press, KNUST|location=Kumasi|pages=12–13|editor=Dean of Students, KNUST}}</ref> === The College of Agriculture and Natural Resources offers undergraduate programmes leading to the award of a Bachelor of Science degree as well as postgraduate programmes leading to the award of MSc, MPhil or PhD degrees.
==== Undergraduate Programmes ==== BSc degrees are awarded by the College's Faculties with specialisation options in the departments in those Faculties. * BSc Agriculture * BSc Natural Resources Management * BSc Post Harvest Technology * BSc Natural Resources Management (offered by the Faculty of Forest Resource Technology)
==== Postgraduate Programmes ==== The college runs the following postgraduate programmes. * MSc Agroforestry * MSc Wood Technology and Management * MPhil and PhD programmes are run in all Departments of the Faculty of Agriculture

{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of France.svg|150px]]}} '''Corruption in France''' describes the prevention and occurrence of [[corruption]] in [[France]].
France has ratified several important international anti-corruption conventions such as the OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions and the United Nations Convention against Corruption. In general, investors do not consider corruption a problem for doing business in France, and companies operating in France generally have a good reputation of corporate social responsibility.<ref>{{cite web|title=Snapshot of the France Country Profile|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/france/snapshot.aspx|work=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|publisher=GAN Integrity Solutions|accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref>
The French National Assembly have proved two bills for combating tax evasion. However, in recent years there are several corruption scandals involving high-ranking public officials. Public works and the defence industry are considered the most affected by corruption.<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 Investment Climate Statement - France|url=https://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2013/204643.htm|work=The US Department of State|publisher=The US Department of State|accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref>
Transparency International's 2017 Corruption Perception Index ranks the country 23rd place out of 180 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2016|title=Corruption Perception Index 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Extent and perceptions ==
In 2011, [[Transparency International]] concluded in its annual report for 2011 that France does not do enough to stop corruption.<ref>[http://www.english.rfi.fr/economy/20120906-corruption-watchdog-says-france-could-do-better "Corruption watchdog says France could do better", Radio France Internationale, September 6, 2012.]</ref> A [[Taylor Nelson Sofres|TNS Sofres]] poll in October 2011 indicated that 72% of the French public had the perception that politicians are corrupt.<ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/21531035 "Bad smells", The Economist, October 1, 2011.]</ref>
In France in 2009 all major foreign investors and exporters and more than 80 per cent of surveyed executives admitted to 'not being familiar at all' with one of the most important legal frameworks in global business. A cartel constitutes a crime punishable by imprisonment and/or fines. Staff and budgets for public enforcement of securities regulation was ca one third in France compared to UK in 2008.<ref name=GCR2009>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/46187/739801 Global Corruption Report 2009], Corruption and the Private Sector, [[Transparency International]] August 2009</ref>
== Areas ==
=== Elections === Political corruption studies include the presidential campaign 2007 finance investigation in the value of 150,000 € from [[Liliane Bettencourt]] to [[Nicolas Sarkozy]]. Maximum individual support is 4,600 €. [[Jacques Chirac]] was accused of using public funds for his election campaign in Paris in the 1990s.<ref name=korruptio>Korruptio mädättää Ranskaa HS 7.11.2011 B4 {{fi}}</ref> On 15 December 2011, Chirac was found guilty and given a suspended sentence of two years.<ref name="BBC guilty 15 December">{{cite news|title=French ex-President Jacques Chirac guilty of corruption|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-16194089|work=BBC |accessdate=15 December 2011|date=15 December 2011}}</ref> He was convicted of diverting public funds, abuse of trust and illegal conflict of interest. The suspended sentence meant he did not have to go to prison, and took into account his age, health, and status as a former head of state.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/15/jacques-chirac-guilty-corruption "Jacques Chirac found guilty of corruption"], ''Guardian'', 15 December 2011.</ref> He did not attend his trial, since medical doctors deemed that his neurological problems damaged his memory.<ref name="BBC guilty 15 December" />
=== Bribery === Bribery investigations from South Africa to France are ongoing, including bribery claims of [[Jacques Chirac]], [[Dominique de Villepin]] and [[Jean-Marie Le Pen]] bribery claim from Gabon ex-president [[Omar Bongo]]. In September 2011 was judged [[Bernard Granie]] of 300 000 bribery from Provence Recyclage.<ref name="korruptio"/>
=== Energy sector === [[Alstom]] has been under investigation in [[France]] and [[Switzerland]] for allegedly making improper payments of US$200 million for contracts for Brazil's Itá hydroelectric plant, for São Paulo's subway expansion and for other major works in Venezuela, Singapore and Indonesia. The Mexican government has penalised Alstom and in 2007 the European Commission's antitrust authority fined Alstom €65 million for price fixing with competitors.<ref name="GCR2009"/>

revision.text:
'''Crime in [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]]''', as with many other countries and territories in [[Crime and violence in Latin America|Latin America and the Caribbean]], is considerably higher than in other parts of the world. Most violence and criminal activity in the country is believed to be gang and drug related.<ref name=Profile>{{cite web|url=http://issat.dcaf.ch/Learn/Resource-Library/Country-Profiles/Saint-Kitts-and-Nevis-Country-Profile|title=Saint Kitts and Nevis – Country Profile|publisher=ISSAT|date=11 February 2015|accessdate=21 April 2017}}</ref>
In 2012 Saint Kitts and Nevis had a homicide rate of 33.6 per 100,000 citizens, the [[List of countries by intentional homicide rate#By country|8th highest]] in the world.<ref name=UNODC>[https://www.unodc.org/gsh/en/index.html ''Global Study on Homicide''. [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]], 2013.]</ref> As of 2011 [[Basseterre]] had the highest murder rate of any capital city in the world at 131.6 per 100,000 inhabitants (a total of 17 murders in the city that year).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/gallery/2014/jun/24/10-world-cities-highest-murder-rates-homicides-in-pictures|title=The 10 world cities with the highest murder rates – in pictures |author=Nick Van Mead and Jo Blason|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=14 June 2014|accessdate=25 April 2017}}</ref>
==Context and History== Saint Kitts and Nevis gained its independence in 1983. In 2001 the country's homicide rate was at an all time low with only 6 murders reported that year. Since then however there has been a rapid rise in homicides and other crimes. 2011 was the worst year for homicides in the country with 34 murders reported, giving the country a homicide rate of 67.6 per 100,000 citizens, at that time one of the top three in the world.<ref name=Profile/><ref name=UNODC/> Since 2011 measures and precautions have been placed by the government that have reduced the number of murders. The Saint Kitts government has also claimed that these measures more than halved crime during that period although this claim has been viewed skeptically by independent organizations.<ref name=Profile/>
Generally speaking the courts and police in Saint Kitts and Nevis are considered effective and corruption free, and the legal system is considered effective.<ref name=Profile/> However there is a lack of civilian oversight and interaction with the police department, as well as occasional reports of abuse perpetrated by the police.<ref name=Profile/> The biggest barrier to fighting crime is seen as the country's outdated prison system, with many, if not all, prisons old and overcrowded. Building new prisons and improving the relationships between the police and community are seen as the biggest improvements the government can make to combat crime.
==Effect on Tourism== Tourism plays a significant role in the Saint Kitts and Nevis economy, and despite the levels of crime tourists are not usually victims. A rare instance of tourists being targeted happened in 2010 when an elderly British couple were murdered in a courtyard.<ref name=Nomads>{{cite web|url=https://www.worldnomads.com/travel-safety/caribbean/saint-kitts-and-nevis/safety-on-st-kitts-and-nevis|title=Safety on St. Kitts & Nevis: The inside story|publisher=World Nomads|first=Phil|last=Sylvester|date=13 June 2015|accessdate=21 April 2017}}</ref>
==Role of Firearms in crime== Firearms have been increasingly used in crimes on Saint Kitts and Nevis. In 2003 only 63.6 percent of murders were gun-related, while in 2010 it had risen to 85 percent. The global average of firearm-related homicides is 42 percent.<ref name=Profile/><ref>{{cite news|title=2016: Homicides 24, murder convictions 0|url=http://www.thestkittsnevisobserver.com/local-news/2016-homicides-24-murder-convictions-0/|date=23 September 2016|accessdate=29 April 2017|last=Washington|first=Monique|publisher=[[The St. Kitts-Nevis Observer]]}}</ref>
==Drugs and gangs== Since the turn of the 21st century there has been an increase in gang and drug-related violence and crime. [[Cocaine]] especially is known to be frequently trafficked through the country, although the presence of the drug trade is considered relatively minor compared to other Caribbean and Latin American countries. Transnational gangs are not believed to operate in the country.<ref name=Profile/>
Most gang activities relate to drug trafficking as well as petty crime, robberies, and extortion. Many homicides and attempted homicides are believed to be drug and gang-related, many caused by rival factions fighting over turf.<ref name=Profile/>
A rivalry starting in 2008 is credited with the escalation of violence in the country. The Saint Kitts and Nevis government eventually arrested several gang leaders, one of which was later executed by hanging.<ref name=Nomads/>
==Criminalization of Homosexuality== [[LGBT rights in Saint Kitts and Nevis|Male homosexuality]] is considered a crime in Saint Kitts in Nevis. By law homosexuality will result in 10 years in prison, and male-on-male assault can be punished with 4 years imprisoned. However actual prosecution of homosexuality is rare, as many members of the LGTB community have hidden their sexual identity due to social stigma.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/49b92b2614.html|title=Saint Kitts and Nevis: The situation of homosexuals; state protection and availability of support groups|work=refworld|date=26 June 2008|accessdate=21 April 2017}}</ref>
==BBC controversy== In 2015 Saint Kitts and Nevis was named by the [[BBC]] in a report as "the most violent place on earth". The BBC's report was widely criticized in Saint Kitts and Nevis for exaggerating the level of violence and crime in the country. The police department of Saint Kitts and Nevis released a report shortly afterwards stating that crime in the country had fallen 60% in the time period from 2011 and 2015, as well as the fact that visitors and tourist to Saint Kitts and Nevis are rarely targeted.<ref>{{cite web|title=St Kitts angered as country named among ‘most dangerous places on the earth’|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/St-Kitts-angered-as-country-named-among--most-dangerous-places-on-the-earth-|date=20 June 2015|accessdate=21 April 2017|work=Jamaica Observer}}</ref>

{{more footnotes|date=November 2015}}
'''Dansaekhwa''' ({{lang-ko|단색화}}), also known as "Tansaekhwa" refers to a loose grouping of paintings that emerged in Korean painting starting in the mid-1970s, when a group of artists began to push paint, soak canvas, drag pencils, rip paper, and otherwise manipulate the materials of painting. Tansaekhwa means ‘monochrome painting’ in Korean and was used by the critic Lee Yil in 1980 to refer to a group of largely non-figurative paintings painted in neutral hues. Promoted in Seoul, Tokyo, and Paris, Tansaekhwa grew to be the international face of contemporary Korean art and a cornerstone of contemporary Asian art.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kee|first1=Joan|title=Contemporary Korean Art: Tansaekhwa and the Urgency of Method|date=2013|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|isbn=0966350391|pages=384|edition=1}}<!--|accessdate=16 May 2016--></ref>
Figures associated with Tansaekhwa include: [[Cho Yong-ik]], Chung Chang-Sup, [[Chung Sanghwa|Chung Sang-Hwa]], Ha Chonghyun, Heu Hwang, Kim Guiline, Kwon Young-woo, [[Lee Dong-youb|Lee Dong Youb]], [[Lee Ufan]], [[Park Seo-bo|Park Seobo]], Suh Seung-Wong, and Yun Hyong-keun.
==History== Lee Ufan had moved to Japan in 1956, where he established himself with the Mono-ha movement in the late 1960s. In the mid-1970s he introduced his Korean peers to the Tokyo art scene. “Five Korean Artists, Five Kinds of White,” a group show held at Tokyo Gallery in May 1975, is often credited as the first major presentation of the works that later became known as Tansaekhwa. The five featured artists were Kwon Young-woo, Lee Dong Youb, Heu Hwang, Suh Seung-won and Park Seobo.
==Recent attention== In 2013, the first extended scholarly discussion of Tansaekhwa, written by Joan Kee, was published by the University of Minnesota Press. It was a finalist for the annual College Art Association Charles Rufus Morey Prize for the most distinguished book in the history of art, the first book on any aspect of modern and contemporary Asian art to receive this designation.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.collegeart.org/awards/moreyfinalists# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-05-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322211016/http://www.collegeart.org/awards/moreyfinalists# |archive-date=2016-03-22 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=Jenny Jungsil|title=Contemporary Korean Art: Tansaekhwa and the Urgency of Method|journal=Journal of Korean Studies|date=2014|volume=38|pages=157–160|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/594914|accessdate=16 May 2016}}</ref> Starting in 2014, a spate of survey shows in Korea and the United States triggered renewed critical and commercial interest in Dansaekhwa.<ref>{{cite web |last1= Degen|first1=Natasha|last2= Kim|first2=Kibum|year= 2015|title=The Koreans at the Top of the Art World |website=New Yorker |url= http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-koreans-at-the-top-of-the-art-world |access-date= 2 December 2015}}</ref>
===Group shows=== *"Overcoming the Modern – Dansaekhwa: The Korean Monochrome Movement," Alexander Gray and Associates, New York (February 19 – March 29, 2014) *“The Art of Dansaekhwa” Kukje Gallery, Seoul (August 28 – October 19, 2014) *“From All Sides: Tansaekhwa on Abstraction,” [[Blum & Poe]], Los Angeles (September 13 – November 8, 2014)<ref>{{cite web |last1= Pagel|first1=David|year= 2014|title='From All Sides' at *Blum & Poe sticks to basics to magnificent effect |website=LA Times |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-art-review-from-all-sides-tansaekhwa-on-abstraction-at-blum-poe-20140930-story.html|access-date= 28 November 2015}}</ref> This show was later included in a roundup of L.A.'s best shows of 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Butler|first1=Connie|title=L.A.'s Best, 2014|url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/news/las-best-2014-connie-butler/|website=Art in America|accessdate=16 May 2016}}</ref> *“Korean Abstract Painting,” Gallery Hyundai, Seoul (March 25 – April 22, 2015) *“Dansaekhwa,” a collateral exhibition of the Venice Biennale, Palazzo Contarini-Polignac, Venice, Italy (May 8 – August 15, 2015) *“Dansaekhwa & Minimalism,” Blum & Poe, Los Angeles (January–March 2016); Blum & Poe, New York (May–July 2016)
Since the first of these surveys took place, there have been several solo exhibitions of individual artists:
*Yun Hyong-keun, (first posthumous solo exhibition), [[PKM Gallery]], Seoul (April 15 – May 17, 2015) *Chung Sang-Hwa, [[Gallery Hyundai]], Seoul (July 1 – 30, 2014) *Park Seobo, [[Galerie Perrotin]] in Paris (November 6 – December 20, 2014) *Ha Chonghyun (first US solo exhibition), Blum & Poe, New York (November 7 – December 20, 2014) *Park Seobo (first US solo exhibition), Galerie Perrotin, New York (May 28 – July 3, 2015) *Chung Chang-Sup (first French solo exhibition), Galerie Perrotin, Paris (June 4 – August 1, 2015) *Yun Hyong-keun (first posthumous solo exhibition in the US), Blum & Poe, New York (October 30 – December 23, 2015) *Chung Chang-Sup (first US solo exhibition), Galerie Perrotin, New York (November 3 – December 23, 2015) *Ha Chonghyun, [[Kukje Gallery]], Seoul (September 17 – October 25, 2015) *Lee Ufan, [[Pace Gallery|Pace London]] (September 15 – October 31, 2015) *Kwon Young-woo, Kukje Gallery, Seoul (October 30 – December 6, 2015) *Ha Chonghyun, [[Tina Kim Gallery]], New York (November 6 – December 12, 2015) *Park Seobo (first UK solo exhibition), [[White Cube]], London (January, 2016) *Kwon Young-woo (first US solo exhibition), Blum & Poe, New York (May, 2016) *Cho Yong-ik, [[Sungkok Art Museum]], Seoul (February 26 - April 24, 2016)

''The Art of Dansaekhwa''. (Seoul: Kukje Gallery, 2014). *Liles, Robert. ''Beyond White: Reading Tansaekhwa Today''. [[ArtAsiaPacific]], no.89 (July–August 2014): 76–83. *''Overcoming the Modern: Dansaekhwa, The Korean Monochrome Movement''. Texts by Sam Bardaouil and Till Fellrath. (New York: Alexander Gray Associates, 2014) *Kee, Joan. ''Contemporary Korean Art: Tansakhwa and the Urgency of Method''. (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2013) *Morley, Simon. page.title: Deportation of Afghan refugees from the United States

revision.comment: /* Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act */
revision.text:
'''Deportation of Afghan refugees from the United States''' refers to the [[wikt:refoulment#English|refoulment]] of [[Afghan refugees]] with no criminal conviction<ref name="Castner"/><ref name="trac.syr.edu"/> and the [[wikt:involuntary#English|involuntary]] [[deportation|removal]] of [[Afghan Americans|Afghan-Americans]] who have been convicted of a common [[crime in the United States]].<ref name="Afghan immigrant sentenced to time served"/><ref name="Ahmadi v. Att'y Gen."/> Some of these individuals in [[removal proceedings]] were admitted to the United States in the [[1980s]] with their [[refugee]] family members after escaping from [[genocide]] and [[persecution]],<ref name="Matter of Izatula"/><ref name="Matter of B-"/><ref name="Mashiri v. Ashcroft"/> and have continuously spent decades as [[wikt:immigrant#English|legal immigrants]] (potential [[national of the United States|U.S. nationals]]).<ref name="national of the United States"/><ref name="immigrant"/><ref name="60 FR 7885"/><ref name="Ali v. Ashcroft"/><ref name="Ahmadi v. Att'y Gen."/><ref name="Jaghoori v. Holder"/>
According to the [[Immigration and Nationality Act]] (INA), the Afghan-Americans did not enter the United States with [[visa policy of the United States#Overview|immigrant visas]] as [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|lawful permanent residents]] but rather with special [[advance parole|travel documents]] as [[Afghan refugees|refugees]].<ref name="Smriko v. Ashcroft"/><ref name="admission"/><ref name="refugee"/> As such, they have been [[wikt:immunize#English|immunized]] against [[deportation]] from the United States since 1980 when the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] enacted INA §§ 207 and 209, 8 U.S.C. §§ 1157 and 1159.<ref name="Coordination with section 1182"/><ref name="Admission by Attorney General of refugees"/><ref name="Matter of B-R-"/><ref name="deferral of removal"/> This legal finding is supported by latest [[precedent]]s of all the [[United States courts of appeals|U.S. courts of appeals]] and the [[Board of Immigration Appeals]] (BIA),<ref name="waiver of inadmissibility">''Matter of J-H-J-'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/pages/attachments/2015/05/12/3836_0.pdf 26 I&N Dec. 563] ([[Board of Immigration Appeals|BIA]] 2015) (collecting court cases) ("An alien who [[adjustment of status|adjusted status]] in the United States, and who '''has not entered''' as a [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|lawful permanent resident]], is not barred from establishing eligibility for a [[United States Waiver of Inadmissibility|waiver of inadmissibility]] under section 212(h) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, {{uscsub|8|1182|h}} (2012), as a result of an [[aggravated felony]] conviction.") (emphasis added); ''De Leon v. Lynch'', [https://casetext.com/case/cristian-eduardo-obregon-de-leon-v-lynch#p1232 808 F.3d 1224], 1232 ([[United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit|10th Cir.]] 2015) ("Mr. Obregon next claims that even if he is removable, he should nevertheless have been afforded the opportunity to apply for a waiver under {{uscsub|8|1182|h}}. Under controlling precedent from our court and the BIA's recent decision in ''Matter of J–H–J–'', he is correct."); see also ''Matter of Abdelghany'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3796.pdf 26 I&N Dec. 254] (BIA 2014) ("A lawful permanent resident who is otherwise eligible for relief under former section 212(c) of the Act may apply for such relief in [[removal proceedings|removal or deportation proceedings]] without regard to whether the relevant conviction resulted from a plea agreement or a trial and without regard to whether he or she was removable or deportable under the law in effect when the conviction was entered."); ''Ledezma-Galicia v. Holder'', [https://casetext.com/case/ledezma-galicia-v-holder 599 F.3d 1055] (9th Cir. 2010) ("We conclude that he may not be removed, because (1) the 1988 law that made aliens deportable for aggravated felony convictions did not apply to convictions prior to November 18, 1988; and (2) neither Congress's overhaul of the grounds for deportation in 1990 nor its rewrite of the definition of aggravated felony in 1996 erased that temporal limitation.").</ref> which are [[wikt:binding#English|binding]] on all [[Immigration Judge (United States)|immigration judges]] and [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS) officers.<ref name="BIA"/><ref name="Deprivation Of Rights Under Color Of Law"/><ref name="sections 241-249"/><ref name="War crimes"/><ref name="CAT"/><ref name="CQ Press"/><ref name="Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez"/><ref name="60 FR 7885"/>
== History == {{Further|Afghanistan–United States relations}} An Afghan-American in [[removal proceedings|deportation proceedings]] has been reported in 1945. The immigration officials [[cancellation of removal|suspended]] (cancelled) his deportation, which allowed him to remain in the United States with his [[Americans|American]] family.<ref>''Matter of K-'', [https://casetext.com/case/in-the-matter-of-k-27 2 I&N 253] (BIA 1945; A.G. 1945) ("The respondent is a 43-year-old native and citizen of Afghanistan, of the Afghan race, who last entered the United States at Portland, Oreg., on June 11, 1926, as a deserting seaman.... [He] is married to a native-born American citizen and is the father of three native-born minor children, all of whom are dependent upon him for support....").</ref>
===Afghans escaping from genocide and persecution in Afghanistan=== {{Further|Saur Revolution}} [[Afghanistan]] began to experience a great [[wikt:turmoil#English|turmoil]] in the [[1970s]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1077209.html|title=U.S.: Afghan Jews Keep Traditions Alive Far From Home|date=June 19, 2007|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty (RFE/RL)|work=Nikola Krastev|accessdate=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref name="Bowersox">{{cite book|title=The Gem Hunter: The Adventures of an American in Afghanistan|last1=Bowersox|first1=Gary W.|year=2004|publisher=GeoVision, Inc.,|location=United States|isbn=0-9747-3231-1|pages=100–03|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=WVAN9pjnRzMC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA100#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2018-10-25}}</ref><ref name="Afghan-American Family Finds Ramadan Good Opportunity for Reflection">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cGRP_jH4DAk |title=Afghan-American Family Finds Ramadan Good Opportunity for Reflection |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=2018-10-04 |publisher=[[Voice of America]] (VOA)}}</ref><ref name="Little Kabul">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gsJo9SvPH2I |title=Little Kabul -- An Afghan American Community in California |work=dingopanga |date=October 21, 2011 |accessdate=2018-10-04 |publisher=}}</ref> which resulted in a mass [[wikt:exodus#English|exodus]] of its citizens, who were first admitted to neighboring [[Afghans in Pakistan|Pakistan]] and [[Afghans in Iran|Iran]] as [[refugee]]s escaping from: (1) [[genocide]] that was orchestrated by the [[communism|communist]] [[People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan]] (PDPA); and (2) [[political repression]] of the [[mujahideen#Afghanistan|mujahideen]], who were engaged in a [[guerrilla warfare]] with the PDPA.<ref name="Matter of Izatula">''Matter of Izatula'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2012/08/14/3127.pdf 20 I&N Dec. 149], 154 (BIA 1990) ("Afghanistan is a [[totalitarianism|totalitarian state]] under the control of the [[People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan|[People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan]]], which is kept in power by the [[Soviet Union]].").</ref><ref name="Matter of B-">''Matter of B-'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3251.pdf 21 I&N Dec. 66], 72 (BIA 1995) ([[en banc]]) ("We further find, however, that the past [[persecution]] suffered by the applicant was so severe that his asylum application should be granted notwithstanding the change of circumstances.").</ref><ref name="Matter of B-R-"/><ref name="Mashiri v. Ashcroft">''Mashiri v. Ashcroft'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/20041495383f3d111211374 383 F.3d 1112], 1120 (9th Cir. 2004) ("[[Persecution]] may be [[emotional]] or [[psychological]], as well as physical."); see also {{cite web |title=The Limits of Soviet Airpower: The Failure of Military Coercion in Afghanistan, 1979-89 |url=https://journals.lib.unb.ca/index.php/jcs/article/view/4356/5011 |publisher= |year=1999 |accessdate=2018-10-20 |last=Westermann |first=Edward B.}}</ref> Iran and Pakistan have never provided [[citizenship]] or [[permanent residency]] to these [[Afghan refugees]].
In 1980, the U.S. Congress and the [[Presidency of Jimmy Carter|Carter administration]] enacted the [[Refugee Act]], which approved 50,000 international refugees to be [[third country resettlement|resettled]] in the United States each year.<ref name="refugee">{{uscsub|8|1101|a|42}} ("The term 'refugee' means (A) '''any person who''' is outside any country of such person’s [[nationality]] or, in the case of a person having no nationality, '''is outside any country in which such person last habitually resided''', and who is unable ... to return to, and is unable ... to avail himself or herself of the protection of, that country because of [[persecution]] or a well-founded fear of persecution on account of [[race (human categorization)|race]], [[religion]], [[nationality]], membership in a [[particular social group]], or political opinion....") (emphasis added).</ref><ref name="Hanna v. Holder"/> Before enacting the Refugee Act, Congress was well aware of the fact that these refugees are not [[priest]]s and [[nun]]s but ordinary people prone to committing a crime just like [[Americans]] commit a [[crime in the United States]].<ref name="Matter of D-X- & Y-Z-">''Matter of D-X- & Y-Z-'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3737.pdf 25 I&N Dec. 664], 666 (BIA 2012) ("It is well settled that an alien is not faulted for using fraudulent documents to escape [[persecution]] and seek [[asylum in the United States]]."); see also {{uscsub|8|1101|a|43|P}}; {{uscsub|8|1227|a|3|C|ii}}.</ref><ref>''United States v. Otherson'', [https://casetext.com/case/united-states-v-otherson 637 F.2d 1276] (9th Cir. 1980), ''cert. denied'', 454 U.S. 840 (1981), (U.S. [[immigration officer]] convicted of serious federal crimes); see also ''United States v. Maravilla'', [https://casetext.com/case/us-v-maravilla 907 F.2d 216] ([[1st Cir.]] 1990) (U.S. immigration officers kidnapped, robbed and [[murder]]ed a visiting foreign businessman).</ref>
===Firm resettlement of Afghan refugees in the United States=== {{Further|Lawful permanent residents (United States)}} Each year, from 1980 onward, groups of Afghan refugee families lawfully entered the United States.<ref name="admission">{{uscsub|8|1101|a|13|A}} ("The terms 'admission' and 'admitted' mean, with respect to an alien, the '''lawful entry''' of the alien into the United States after inspection and authorization by an immigration officer.") (emphasis added); ''Matter of D-K-'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3747.pdf 25 I&N Dec. 761], 765-66 (BIA 2012).</ref><ref name="Smriko v. Ashcroft">''Smriko v. Ashcroft'', [https://casetext.com/case/smriko-v-ashcroft#p287 387 F.3d 279], 287 (3d Cir. 2004) (explaining that the idea of refugees being admitted to the United States as lawful permanent residents was intentionally rejected by the [[United States congressional conference committee|U.S. Congressional Conference Committee]]); H.R. Conf. Rep. No. 96-781, at 21 (1980), ''reprinted in'' 1980 U.S.C.C.A.N. 160, 162.</ref> These families were issued by the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]] special [[advance parole|travel documents]]. At least one such family entered with fraudulent documents and applied for [[asylum in the United States]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=König |first1=Karin |title=Detained, Denied, Deported: Asylum Seekers in the United States |date=1989 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |isbn=9780929692227 |page=45 |url=https://books.google.com |language=en}}</ref><ref name="Matter of D-X- & Y-Z-"/> After residing for at least one year in the United States, the then [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]] (INS) [[adjustment of status|adjusted their status]] to that of [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|lawful permanent residents]] (green card holders).<ref name="Ali v. Ashcroft">''Ali v. Ashcroft'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/20051117395f3d72211044 395 F.3d 722] ([[7th Cir.]] 2005).</ref><ref name="Ahmadi v. Att'y Gen."/><ref name="Jaghoori v. Holder">''Jaghoori v. Holder'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/infco20141118092 772 F.3d 764] ([[4th Cir.]] 2014).</ref> This process statutorily protected them from [[wikt:refoulment#English|refoulment]] (forceful [[deportation]]) for [[wikt:lifetime#English|lifetime]].<ref name="immigrant"/><ref name="section 1101(a)(13)(C)(v)"/><ref name="Coordination with section 1182"/><ref name="Admission by Attorney General of refugees"/><ref name="Matter of Z-Z-O-">''Matter of Z-Z-O-'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/pages/attachments/2015/05/26/3838.pdf 26 I&N Dec. 586] (BIA 2015) ("Whether an asylum applicant has an objectively reasonable fear of persecution based on the events that the [[Immigration Judge (United States)|Immigration Judge]] found may occur upon the applicant's return to the country of removal is a legal determination that is subject to de novo review.").</ref><ref name="Matter of Izatula"/><ref name="Matter of B-"/><ref name="deferral of removal"/>
These refugee families were distributed all across the United States. Most were ''[[third country resettlement|firmly resettled]]'' in and around [[New York City]], [[California]], [[Northern Virginia]], [[Florida]], and [[Texas]]. In ''[[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 459|Landon v. Plasencia]]'', [https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/459/21/ 459 U.S. 21], 32 (1982), the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] reminded the [[United States Attorney General|U.S. Attorney General]] that "once an [[alien (law)#United States|alien]] gains admission to our country and begins to develop the ties that go with [[permanent residency|permanent residence]], his [[United States Constitution|constitutional]] status changes accordingly." That opinion was issued after Congress and the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan administration]] ''firmly resettled'' in the United States refugees from various countries.<ref name="Hanna v. Holder">See generally ''Hanna v. Holder'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/infco20140117075 740 F.3d 379] (6th Cir. 2014) (discussing firm resettlement); ''Matter of A-G-G-'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3713.pdf 25 I&N Dec. 486] (BIA 2011) (same).</ref><ref name="Matter of B-R-"/>
===United States Congress provides statutory relief to Afghan-Americans against removability=== {{Further|Afghan Americans|Cancellation of removal|United States Waiver of Inadmissibility}} The INA historically stated that "[t]he term '[[alien (law)#United States|alien]]' means any person not a [[citizenship of the United States|citizen]] '''or''' [[national of the United States]]."<ref name="alien">{{uscsub|8|1101|a|3}} (emphasis added); see also {{uscsub|8|1101|a|22}} ("The term '[[national of the United States]]' means (A) a [[citizenship of the United States|citizen of the United States]], '''or (B) a person who, though not a citizen of the United States, owes permanent allegiance to the United States'''.") (emphasis added); ''Ricketts v. Att'y Gen.'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/infco20180730056 897 F.3d 491], 493-94 n.3 (3d Cir. 2018) ("[[Citizenship]] and [[nationality]] are not [[synonym|synonymous]]."); {{uscsub|8|1101|a|31}} ("The term '[[wikt:permanent|permanent]]' means a relationship of continuing or lasting nature, as distinguished from temporary, but a relationship may be permanent even though it is one that may be dissolved eventually at the instance either of the United States or of the individual, in accordance with law."); {{uscsub|8|1101|a|33}} ("The term '[[residence]]' means the place of general [[dwelling|abode]]; the place of general abode of a person means his principal, actual [[dwelling]] place in fact, without regard to intent."); [[Black's Law Dictionary]] at p.87 (9th ed., 2009) (defining the term "permanent allegiance" as "[t]he lasting [[allegiance]] owed to [the United States] by its citizens '''or''' [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|[lawful permanent resident]s]].") (emphasis added).</ref> The terms "inadmissible aliens" and "deportable aliens" are [[synonym]]ous.<ref name="Galindo v. Sessions">''Galindo v. Sessions'', 897 F.3d 894, ___, [https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/ca7/17-1253/17-1253-2018-07-31.html No. 17-1253], p.4-5 ([[7th Cir.]] July 31, 2018) (explaining that under the INA inadmissible aliens and deportable aliens are [[synonymous]]).</ref><ref name="removable"/> If an Afghan-American is not inadmissible to the United States then he or she is plainly and unambiguously not removable from the United States.<ref name="section 1101(a)(13)(C)(v)"/><ref name="Matter of B-R-">''Matter of B-R-'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3780_correction.pdf 26 I&N Dec. 119], 122 (BIA 2013) ("The core regulatory purpose of asylum . . . is . . . to protect refugees with nowhere else to turn.") (brackets and internal quotation marks omitted).</ref><ref name="Ahmadi v. Att'y Gen."/> Anything to the contrary will make deportation from the United States a paid [[international]] [[vacation]] for him or her and a "[[cruel and unusual punishment]]" for others.<ref name="persecution">See generally ''Matter of Smriko'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3520.pdf 23 I&N Dec. 836] (BIA 2005) (three-member panel blatantly [[persecution|persecuting]] refugees and depriving them of [[human rights in the United States|rights]] by not giving any effect to the plain text of 8 U.S.C. §§ 1157(c)(3) and 1159(c)); ''Maiwand v. Gonzales'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/2007602501f3d1011602 501 F.3d 101], 106-07 (2d Cir. 2007) (same; [[wikt:cursory#English|cursory]] [[judicial opinion|opinion]]); ''Romanishyn v. Att'y Gen.'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/2006630455f3d1751628 455 F.3d 175] (3d Cir. 2006) (same; cursory opinion); ''Kaganovich v. Gonzales'', [https://www.leagle.com/decision/20061364470f3d89411358 F.3d 894] (9th Cir. 2006) (same; cursory opinion).</ref><ref name="Mashiri v. Ashcroft"/> For example, some deportees could successfully make the U.S. government pay them hundreds of thousands<ref name="damages"/><ref name="Sakuma"/> (or possibly millions<ref>''Harvey v. Chertoff'', [https://casetext.com/case/harvey-v-chertoff#p190 263 F. App'x. 188], 190 (3d Cir. 2008) ("Harvey sought money [[damages]] in the amount of $15 million.") (non-precedential); see also ''Allen v. Holder'', [https://casetext.com/case/allen-v-holder-4#p3 Civil Action No. 13-5736], p.3 ([[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey|D.N.J.]] Aug. 16, 2016) ("He also seeks $5,000,000 in damages.").</ref><ref name="Ahmadi v. Att'y Gen."/>) of dollars while others could end up committing [[suicide]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Afghan Migrant Deported From Germany Kills Himself |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |date=July 11, 2018|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/afghan-migrant-deported-from-germany-kills-himself-on-return-home/29357257.html |accessdate=2018-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Cambodian-Americans confronting deportation |publisher=[[Boston Globe]] |date=January 27, 2013|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/magazine/2013/01/27/cambodian-americans-confronting-deportation/MK3TQy80UJyG2HjfKKtEIO/story.html |accessdate=2018-10-18 |work=Olesia Plokhii and Tom Mashberg}}</ref>
In this regard, INA § 207(c), 8 U.S.C. § 1157(c), expressly provides the following:{{Quote|'''The provisions of''' paragraphs (4), (5), and (7)(A) of '''[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/8/1182#a_4 section 1182(a)]''' . . . '''''shall''''' not be applicable to any alien seeking admission to the United States under [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/8/1157#c this subsection], '''and the [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] may waive any other provision of [section 1182]''' . . . with respect to such an alien for <u>[[wikt:humanitarian#English|humanitarian]] purposes, to assure [[family]] unity, '''or''' when it is otherwise in the [[public interest]]</u>. (emphasis added).<ref name="Admission by Attorney General of refugees">{{uscsub|8|1157|c|3}} ''[[cf.]]'' ''Matter of Jean'', [https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2014/07/25/3472.pdf 23 I&N Dec. 373] ([[United States Attorney General|A.G.]] 2002) (former Attorney General [[John Ashcroft]] unconstitutionally altering the text of 8 U.S.C. § 1159(c), which he has no authority to do so, and blatantly depriving all refugees of their [[human rights in the United States|protected rights]] simply because of one criminal act of one [[Haitian diaspora|Haitian foreign national]]).</ref><ref name="Jennings v. In addition to the above provisions, INA § 212(h), 8 U.S.C. § 1182(h), provides the following:{{Quote|The Attorney General may, in his [[discretion]], waive the application of subparagraphs (A)(i)(I), (B), (D), and (E) of subsection (a)(2) . . . if. . . it is established to the satisfaction of the Attorney General that. . . the [[crime in the United States|[crime]]] for which the alien is [removable] occurred more than 15 years before the date of the alien's application for a [[visa policy of the United States|visa]], [[immigration to the United States|admission]], or [[adjustment of status]], . . . the admission to the United States of such alien would not be contrary to the [[wikt:national#English|national]] welfare, safety, or security of the United States, and . . . the alien has been [[wikt:rehabilitate#English|rehabilitated]]; '''or''' . . . in the case of an [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|immigrant]] who is the [[spouse]], [[parent]], [[son]], or [[daughter]] of a [[citizenship of the United States|citizen of the United States]] <u>or an [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence]]</u> if it is established to the satisfaction of the Attorney General that the alien's denial of admission would result in [[extreme hardship]] to the United States citizen or [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|lawfully resident]] spouse, parent, son, or daughter of such alien. . . .
