[[File:Killing fur seals, St Paul Island.jpg|thumb|262x262px|Killing [[fur seal]]s on [[Saint Paul Island (Alaska)|St Paul Island]], [[Territory of Alaska|Alaska Territory]], 1890s.]] [[File:Seal-skinning on the floes.jpg|thumb|262x262px|Seal [[skinning]] in the late 1800s]] '''Seal hunting''', or '''sealing''', is the personal or commercial hunting of [[Pinniped|seals]]. Seal hunting is currently practiced in nine countries and one region of Denmark: United States (above the Arctic Circle in Alaska), Canada, Namibia, Iceland, Norway, Russia, Finland, Sweden, and Greenland. Most of the world's seal hunting takes place in Canada and Greenland.
[[Fisheries and Oceans Canada|The Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans]] (DFO) regulates the seal hunt in Canada. It sets quotas (total allowable catch – TAC), monitors the hunt, studies the seal population, works with the Canadian Sealers' Association to train sealers on new regulations, and promotes sealing through its website and spokespeople. The DFO set harvest quotas of over 90,000 seals in 2007; 275,000 in 2008; 280,000 in 2009; and 330,000 in 2010.<ref name=faq-canada>{{cite web|url=http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/fm-gp/seal-phoque/faq-eng.htm |title=Frequently Asked Questions About Canada's Seal Harvest |publisher=Fisheries and Oceans Canada |date=2011-03-17 |accessdate=2011-07-23|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181704/http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/fm-gp/seal-phoque/faq-eng.htm|archivedate=2011-07-06}}</ref> The actual kills in recent years have been less than the quotas: 82,800 in 2007; 217,800 in 2008; 72,400 in 2009; and 67,000 in 2010.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/fm-gp/seal-phoque/seal_harp_%202009-eng.pdf|title=Current Status of Northwest Atlantic Harp Seals, ''Pagophilus groenlandicus''|publisher=Fisheries and Oceans Canada|date=March 2010|author=Canadian Science Advisory Secretariat|journal=Science Advisory Report}}</ref>
In 2007, Norway claimed that 29,000 harp seals were killed, Russia claimed that 5,479 seals were killed, and Greenland claimed that 90,000 seals were killed in their respective seal hunts.
[[Harp seal]] populations in the northwest Atlantic declined to approximately 2 million in the late 1960s as a result of Canada's annual kill rates, which averaged to over 291,000 from 1952 to 1970.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ifaw.org/sites/default/files/2009%20seal%20sealing.pdf|title=Canada's Commercial Sea Slaughter 2009|publisher=International Fund for Animal Welfare|last=Fink|first=Sheryl}}</ref> Conservationists demanded reduced rates of killing and stronger regulations to avert the extinction of the harp seal. In 1971, the Canadian government responded by instituting a quota system. The system was competitive, with each boat catching as many seals as it could before the hunt closed, which the Department of Fisheries and Oceans did when they knew that year's quota had been reached. Because it was thought that the competitive element might cause sealers to cut corners, new regulations were introduced that limited the catch to 400 seals per day, and 2000 per boat total. A 2007 population survey conducted by the DFO estimated the population at 5.5 million. {{Citation needed|date=October 2011}}
It is illegal in Canada to hunt newborn harp seals ([[whitecoats]]) and young [[hooded seal]]s (bluebacks). When the seal pups begin to molt their downy white fur at the age of 12–14 days, they are called "[[ragged-jacket]]" and can be commercially hunted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsi.org/world/canada/work/protect_seals/research/seal_myths_and_facts.html|title=Myths and Facts: The Truth about Canada's Commercial Seal Hunt |publisher=Human Society International: Canada|date=2011-02-04 |accessdate=2009-05-26}}</ref> After molting, the seals are called "beaters", named for the way they beat the water with their flippers.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A20625-2004Apr17?language=printer |title=Activists Decry Growth Of Canadian Seal Hunt |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=2004-04-18 |accessdate=2009-05-26|first=DeNeen L.|last= Brown}}</ref> The hunt remains highly controversial, attracting significant media coverage and protests each year.<ref name=EBindustry>{{cite encyclopedia|title=harp seal (mammal): The sealing industry|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica|year=2008|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/255712/harp-seal/274188/The-sealing-industry|first=Serge|last=Lariviere}}</ref> Images from past hunts have become iconic symbols for [[Conservationism|conservation]], [[animal welfare]], and [[animal rights]] advocates. In 2009, Russia banned the hunting of harp seals less than one year old.
==History== The term seal is used to refer to a diverse group of animals. In science, they are grouped together in the [[Pinnipeds]], which also includes the [[walrus]], not popularly thought of as a seal, and not considered here. The two main families of seals are the [[Otariidae]] (the eared seals; includes [[sea lion]]s, and [[fur seal]]s), and [[Phocidae]] (the earless seals); animals in the family Phocidae are sometimes referred to as hair seals, and are much more adept in the water than the eared seals, though they have a more difficult time getting around on land. The fur seal yields a valuable fur; the hair seal has no fur, but oil can be obtained from its fat and leather from its hide.<ref name=ea /> Seals have been used for their pelts, their flesh, and their fat, which was often used as [[oil lamp|lamp fuel]], [[lubricant]]s, [[cooking oil]], a constituent of soap, the liquid base for [[red ochre]] paint, and for processing materials such as leather and [[jute]].
===Traditional seal hunting=== [[File:Eskimo Seal Hunting.jpg|thumb|[[Inuit]] seal hunting]] Archeological evidence indicates the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] and [[First Nations]] People in Canada have been hunting seals for at least 4,000 years. Traditionally, when an [[Inuit]] boy killed his first seal or [[caribou]], a feast was held. The [[Seal meat|meat]] was an important source of fat, protein, vitamin A, vitamin B<sub>12</sub> and iron,<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=17514649 |title=Nutritional composition of blubber and meat of hooded seal and harp seal|last=Brunborg |first=Linn Anne|last2=Julshamn |first2=Kare|last3= Nortvedt|first3= Ragnar|last4=Frøyland|first4= Livar |journal=Food Chemistry|pages=524–531|volume=96|year=2006|accessdate=2011-03-03|issue=4|doi=10.1016/j.foodchem.2005.03.005}}</ref> and the pelts were prized for their warmth. The Inuit diet is rich in fish, whale, and seal.
There were approximately 150,000 circumpolar Inuit in 2005 in Greenland, Alaska, Russia, and Canada.<ref name=Ejesiak /> According to Kirt Ejesiak, former secretary and chief of staff to then-Premier of Nunavut, Paul Okalik and the first Inuk from Nunavut to attend Harvard, for the c. 46,000 Canadian Inuit, the seal was not "just a source of cash through fur sales, but the keystone of their culture. Although Inuit harvest and hunt many species that inhabit the desert tundra and ice platforms, the seal is their mainstay. The Inuktitut vocabulary designates specific objects made from seal bone, sinew, fat and fur used as tools, games, thread, cords, fuel, clothing, boats, and tents. There are also words referring to seasons, topography, place names, legends, and kinship relationships based on the seal. One region of Canada's north is inhabited by the [[Netsilik Inuit|''Netsilingmiut'']], or "people of the seal."<ref name=Ejesiak>{{citation|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2005/05/08/animal_rights_vs_inuit_rights/ |title=Animal rights vs. Inuit rights |first=Kirt |last=Ejesiak |date=8 May 2005 |accessdate=8 May 2010 |publisher=Boston Globe |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104032832/http://www.boston.com/news/globe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2005/05/08/animal_rights_vs_inuit_rights/ |archivedate=November 4, 2012 }}</ref><ref name="WenzelControversy" /> The title of Ejesiak's article acknowledged the pivotal 1991 publication entitled ''Animal Rights, Human Rights'' by George Wenzel, a McGill University geographer and anthropologist who worked more than two decades with the Clyde Inuit of Baffin Island. Wenzel's "scholarly examination" of "the impact of the animal rights movement upon the culture and economy of the Canadian Inuit" was among the first to reveal how animal rights groups, "well-meaning people in the dominant society through misunderstanding and ignorance can inflict destruction" on a vulnerable minority.<ref name=AINA>{{cite journal|first=Rick |last=Riewe|volume= 45|number=2|year=1992|title=Riview of Animal Rights, Human Rights: Ecology, Economy and Ideology in the Canadian Arctic by George Wenzel|format= PDF|doi=10.14430/arctic1859|journal=Arctic Institute of North America|url=http://arctic.synergiesprairies.ca/arctic/index.php/arctic/article/viewFile/1859/1837|accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref>
Inuit seal hunting accounts for the majority of the seal hunt, but just three percent of the hunt in southern Canada; it is excluded from the [[European Commission]]'s call in 2006 for a ban on the import, export and sale of all harp and hooded seal products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eubusiness.com/Environ/060906222345.cyu8d8wj|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080416235153/http://www.eubusiness.com/Environ/060906222345.cyu8d8wj|archivedate=2008-04-16 |title=Euro MPs call for ban on seal products|publisher= EUbusiness|date=2006-09-07 |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref> [[Ringed seal]]s were once the main staple for food, and have been used for clothing, boots, fuel for lamps, as delicacy, containers, [[igloo]] windows, and in harnesses for [[huskies]]. Though no longer used to this extent, ringed seals are still an important food and clothing source for the people of [[Nunavut]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Mike|last=Vlessides|chapter=Marine Mammals|postscript=|title=Nunavut Handbook}} cited in {{cite web|url=http://inuitarteskimoart.com/artists/About-Seals.html |title=Eskimo Art, Inuit Art, Canadian Native Artwork, Canadian Aboriginal Artwork |publisher=ABoriginArt Inc |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref> Called ''nayiq'' by the [[Central Alaskan Yup'ik]] people, the ringed seal is also hunted and eaten in [[Alaska]].
Seals were also hunted in northwest Europe and the [[Baltic Sea]] more than 10,000 years ago.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
===Early modern era=== [[File:Reimerswaal ¿ Zeehondenjacht.jpg|thumb|Seal hunting in [[Verdronken Land van Reimerswaal|Reimerswaal]]]]
The first commercial hunting of seals by Europeans, is said to have occurred in 1515, when a cargo of fur seal skins from Uruguay was sent to Spain for sale in the markets of [[Seville]].<ref name=tas-history />
====Newfoundland==== [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] and the [[Gulf of St. Lawrence]] were the first regions to experience large scale sealing. Migratory fishermen began the hunting from as early as the 1500s. Large-scale commercial seal hunting became an annual event starting in 1723 and expanded rapidly near the turn of the 18th century. Initially, the method used was to ensnare the migrating seals in nets anchored to [[Dock (maritime)|shore installations]], known as the 'landsman seal fishery'. The hunt was mainly for the procurement of seal meat as a form of sustenance for the settlements in the area, rather than for commercial gain.<ref name="Seal Fishery">{{cite web|url=http://www.thesealfishery.com/seal_hunt_history1.php|title=Sealing History|publisher=The Seal Fishery}}</ref>
From the early 18th century English hunters began to range further afield - 1723 marked the first time that hunters armed with [[firearm]]s ventured forth in boats to increase their haul. This soon became a sophisticated commercial operation; the seals were transported back to England, where the seal's meat, fur and oil were sold separately. From 1749, the import of seal oil to England was being recorded annually, and was used as a lighting oil, for cooking, in the manufacture of [[soap]] and for the treating of [[leather]].<ref name="Seal Fishery"/>
====South Atlantic==== It was in the [[Atlantic Ocean#South Atlantic|South Seas]] that sealing became a major enterprise from the late 18th century. [[Samuel Enderby]], along with [[Alexander Champion (businessman)|Alexander Champion]] and [[John St Barbe]] organized the first commercial expedition to the [[South Atlantic Ocean]] in 1776, initially with the primary aim of [[whaling]], although sealing began to play a prominent part in the operation as well. More expeditions were sent in 1777 and 1778 before political and economic troubles hampered the trade for some time.<ref>Jackson (1978), p.92.</ref>
On 1 September 1788, the 270 ton ship ''Emilia'', owned by [[Samuel Enderby & Sons]] and commanded by Captain James Shields, departed London. The ship went west around [[Cape Horn]] into the [[Pacific Ocean]] to become the first ship of any nation to conduct operations in the [[Southern Ocean]]. ''Emilia'' returned to London on 12 March 1790 with a cargo of 139 tons of [[Whale oil|sperm oil]].<ref name=Quarterly>[https://books.google.com/books?id=UINZAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA321#v=onepage&q=&f=false The Quarterly Review, Volume 63, London:John Murray, 1839, page 321].</ref>
By 1784, the British had fifteen ships in the southern fishery, all from [[London]]. By 1790 this port alone had sixty vessels employed in the trade. Between 1793 and 1799 there was an average of sixty vessels in the trade. The average increased to seventy-two in the years between 1800 and 1809.<ref>Stackpole (1972), p.282.</ref><ref>Letter from Commander Thomas Melvill to Chas. Enderby & sons in London detailing this catch. [[State Library of New South Wales|Mitchell Library]] Sydney.</ref>
[[File:Cook-1777.PNG|thumb|left|[[South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands|South Georgia island]] became a centre for the sealing industry from the late 18th century, shortly after it was mapped by Captain [[James Cook]] in 1777.]] The sealing industry extended further south to the [[South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands|South Georgia island]], first mapped by Captain [[James Cook]] in {{HMS|Resolution|Cook|6}} on 17 January 1775. During the late 18th century and throughout the 19th century, South Georgia was inhabited by English and [[Yankee]] sealers, who used to live there for considerable periods of time and sometimes overwintered. In 1778, English sealers brought back from the Island of [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]] and the [[Magellan Strait]] area as many as 40,000 seal skins and 2,800 tons of [[elephant seal]] oil. More [[fur seals]] from the island were taken in 1786 by the English sealing vessel ''Lord Hawkesbury'', and by 1791, 102 vessels, manned by 3000 sealers, were hunting seals south of the equator. The first commercial visit to the South Sandwich Islands was made in 1816 by another English ship, the ''Ann''.
The sealers pursued their trade in a most unsustainable manner, promptly reducing the [[fur seal]] population to near extermination. As a result, sealing activities on South Georgia had three marked peaks in 1786–1802, 1814–23, and 1869–1913 respectively, decreasing in between and gradually shifting to [[elephant seal]]s taken for oil.
====Pacific==== Commercial sealing in [[Australasia]] appears to have started with the London-based Massachusetts-born [[Eber Bunker]], master of the ''[[William and Ann (1759)|William and Ann]]'', who announced his intention in November 1791 to visit and hunt in New Zealand's [[Dusky Sound]].<ref name=entwisle>{{cite book|last=Entwisle|first=Peter|title=Behold the Moon: The European Occupation of the Dunedin District 1770–1848|year=1998|publisher=Port Daniel Press|location=Dunedin, NZ|isbn=9780473055912|pages=10–11, 13–15}}</ref>{{rp|10–11|date=December 2012}} Captain [[William Raven]] of the ''[[Britannia (1783 whaler)|Britannia]]'' stationed a party at Dusky from 1792 to 1793, but the discovery in 1798-1799 of [[Bass Strait]], between mainland Australia and Van Diemen's Land (later known as [[Tasmania]]) saw the sealers' focus shift there in 1798, when a gang including Daniel Cooper landed from the ''Nautilus'' on [[Cape Barren Island]].<ref name=mcnab1907>{{cite book|first=Robert|last=McNab|title=Murihiku|location=Invercargill, NZ|year=1907|pages=70–71, 78–79}}</ref>
With Bass Strait over-exploited by 1802, commercial attention returned to southern New Zealand waters, where [[Stewart Island/Rakiura]] and [[Foveaux Strait]] were explored, exploited and charted from 1803 to 1804.<ref>Entwisle pp. 13–15</ref> Thereafter, the sealing-industry focus shifted to the sub-Antarctic [[Antipodes Islands]], 1805–1807, the [[Auckland Islands]] from 1806, the southeast coast of New Zealand's [[South Island]], [[Otago Harbour]] and [[Solander Island]] by 1809, before focusing further to the south at the newly discovered [[Campbell Island, New Zealand|Campbell Island]] (discovered in January 1810) and [[Macquarie Island]] (discovered in July 1810) from 1810.<ref>Entwisle pp. 13–16</ref><ref>{{cite book| publisher = Reed| isbn = 9780589009595| last = Kerr| first = Ian S.| title = Campbell Island: a history| year = 1976|location=Wellington, NZ}}{{page needed|date=December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| publisher = Antarctic Division, Department of External Affairs| last = Cumpston| first = John Stanley| title = Macquarie Island| year = 1968|location= Canberra, Australia}}{{page needed|date=December 2012}}</ref> During this period sealers were active on the southern coast of mainland Australia, for example at [[Kangaroo Island]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Cumpston|first=J.S.|title=Kangaroo Island, 1800–1836|year=1970|publisher=Roebuck Society|location=Canberra}}</ref> This whole development has been called{{by whom|date=September 2014}} the first sealing boom; it sparked the [[Sealers' War]] (1810- ) in southern New Zealand.
By about 1815 sealing in the Pacific had faded in importance. A brief revival occurred from 1823, but this proved very short-lived.<ref name=mcnab1907 /> Although highly profitable at times and affording New South Wales one of its earliest trade staples, sealing's unregulated character saw its self-destruction. Notable traders from Britain and based in Australia included [[Simeon Lord]], [[Henry Kable]], [[James Underwood (carpenter)|James Underwood]] and [[Robert Campbell (1769–1846)|Robert Campbell]]. Plummers of London and the Whitneys of New York also became involved.<ref name=entwisle /><ref>{{cite book|first=Edmund|last= Fanning|title=Voyages Round the World|location= New York, |publisher=Collins and Hannay|year=1833|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=PuUUAAAAMAA}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=rJgvAAAAMAAJ|first=D.R. |last=Hainsworth|title= The Sydney Traders, Simeon Lord and his Contemporaries 1788–1821|location= Melbourne|publisher=Cassell Australia|year= 1971}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=Margaret|last= Steven|title= Merchant Campbell 1769–1846 a Study in the Colonial Trade|location=Melbourne|publisher = Oxford University Press|year= 1965}}</ref>
By 1830 most Pacific seal stocks had been seriously depleted, and [[Lloyd's Register|Lloyd's Register of Shipping]] only showed one full-time sealing vessel on its books.<ref name=tas-history> {{cite web | url = http://www.parks.tas.gov.au/fahan_mi_shipwrecks/infohut/sealing.htm | title = History of World Fur Sealing | last=Roberts | first=Glynn |year=1999}}</ref> In the North Pacific, the later 1800s saw large harvests of fur seals. These harvests decreased along with fur-seal populations.
===Industrial era=== [[File:Sealhunt 550.jpg|thumb|Seal hunting in [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] in the 1880s.]]
Growing from the international [[Grand Banks]] fishery, the Newfoundland hunt initially used small [[schooner]]s. Kill rates averaged 451,000 in the 1830s, and rose to 546,000 annually during the first half of the next decade, which led to a marked decline in the harp seal population that in turn adversely impacted profits in the sealing industry.<ref name="heritage.nf.ca">{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/society/sail_seal.html |title=The Sailing Seal Fishery: Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage |publisher=Memorial University of Newfoundland| first=J.K.|last= Hiller |year=2001|work= Society, Economy and Culture |accessdate=2011-07-23}}</ref>
Sealing reached its peak in [[Newfoundland]] in the 1860s, with the introduction of more powerful and reliable [[steamship]]s that were capable of much larger range and storing capacity.<ref>Chesley Sanger, "Sail versus Steam: Post 1863 Technological and Spatial Adaptation in the Newfoundland Seal Fishery," ''Newfoundland and Labrador Studies,'' Fall 2008, Vol. 23 Issue 2, pp 139–169</ref><ref>Shannon Ryan, ''The Ice Hunters: A History of Newfoundland Sealing to 1914'' (St. John's: Breakwater Books, 1994)</ref> Annual catches exceeded the 400,000 mark from the 1870s and smaller sealers were steadily pushed out of the market.
The first modern sealing ship was the [[USS Bear (1874)|SS ''Bear'']], built in [[Dundee]], Scotland in 1874 as a steamer for [[seal hunt|sealing]].<ref>{{Cite book|publisher=Government Printing Office|last=United States. Revenue-Cutter Service :|title=Report of the cruise of the U.S. Revenue Cutter Bear and the overland expedition for the relief of the whalers in the Arctic ocean, from November 27, 1897, to September 13, 1898|location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=2014-03-23|year=1898|url=https://archive.org/details/reportofcruiseof03unit }}</ref> The ship was custom-built for sealing out of [[St. John's, Newfoundland]], and was the most outstanding sealing vessel of her day and the lead ship in a new generation of sealers.<ref>Tod, Giles, M.S., ''Last Sail Down East'', Barre Publishers, (1965) p. 48</ref> Heavy-built with six inch (15.2 cm) thick wooden planks, ''Bear'' was rigged as a sailing [[barquentine]] but her main power was a steam engine designed to smash deep into ice packs to reach seal herds.
[[File:USS Bear (AG-29) Antarctica c1939.jpg|thumb|left|The [[USS Bear (1874)|SS ''Bear'']] began sealing operations in the 1870s and radically transformed the industry.]] At the time of her arrival in St. John's, there were 300 vessels outfitted each season to hunt seals, but most were small [[schooners]] or old sailing [[barque]]s.<ref>Ryan, Shannon, ''The Ice Hunters: A History of Newfoundland Sealing to 1914'' (1994) Breakwater Books Ltd. {{ISBN|1-55081-095-2}}.</ref> The new sealing ships represented by ''Bear'' radically transformed the Eastern North Atlantic seal fishery as they replaced the hundreds of smaller sealing vessels owned by merchants in [[outports]] around Newfoundland with large and expensive steamships owned by large British and Newfoundland companies based in St. John's.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/law/sealing_disaster.html |title="1914 Sealing Disaster", Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage'' |publisher=Heritage.nf.ca |date= |accessdate=2014-08-05}}</ref> Owned at first by the Scottish firm W. Grieve and Sons, she was acquired in 1880 by R. Steele Junior.<ref>''Lloyds Register'' 1875-1883</ref>
Another famous sealing ship of the era was the ''[[Terra Nova (ship)|Terra Nova]]'', originally built in 1884 for the Dundee whaling and sealing fleet. She was ideally suited to the polar regions and worked for 10 years in the annual seal fishery in the [[Labrador Sea]]. Large and expensive ships required major capital investments from British and Newfoundland firms, and shifted the industry from merchants in small [[outports]] to companies based in [[St. John's, Newfoundland]]. By the late 19th century, the sealing industry in Newfoundland was second in importance only to [[cod fishing in Newfoundland|cod fishing]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.canadiangeographic.ca/Magazine/JF00/sealtimeline.asp |title=Atlantic Canada Seal Hunt – Sealing through the years|journal= Canadian Geographic Magazine |publisher=Canadian Geographic Enterprises|date=January–February 2000 |accessdate=2011-07-23}}</ref>
The seal hunt provided critical winter wages for fishermen, but was dangerous work marked by sealing disasters that claimed hundreds of lives, such as the 1914 Newfoundland Sealing Disaster involving the [[SS Southern Cross (1886)|SS ''Southern Cross'']], the [[SS Newfoundland|SS ''Newfoundland'']], and SS ''Stephano''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/law/sealing_disaster.html |title=1914 Sealing Disaster|work= Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage|first=Jenny|last= Higgins|publisher=Memorial University of Newfoundland |year= 2007|accessdate=2011-03-03}}</ref> The rugged hulls and experienced crews of Newfoundland sealing vessels often led sealers such as ''Bear'' and ''Terra Nova'' to be hired for arctic exploration and one sealer ''Algerine'' was hired to recover ''Titanic'' bodies in 1912. After [[World War II]], the Newfoundland hunt was dominated by large Norwegian sealing vessels until the late 20th century, when the much diminished hunt shifted to smaller motor fishing vessels, based from outports around Newfoundland and Labrador. In 2007, the commercial seal hunt dividend contributed about $6 million to the Newfoundland GDP, a fraction of the industry's former importance.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}
===Environmental protection=== [[Image:Choris, Saint Paul.jpg|thumb|The Russian ''Rurik'', near [[Saint Paul Island (Alaska)|Saint Paul Island]] in the [[Bering sea]]. Sealing in the Bering sea led to a diplomatic dispute between the US and Britain in the 1880s, which brought about the first legislative attempts to limit the environmental damage done by the sealers. Drawing by [[Louis Choris]] in 1817.]]
The end of the 19th century was marked by the [[Bering Sea Controversy]] between the United States and Great Britain over the management of fur seal harvests.<ref name=ea/> In 1867 the United States government purchased from Russia all her territorial rights in [[Alaska]] and the adjacent islands, including the [[Pribilof Islands]], the principal breeding-grounds of the seals in those seas. By [[Acts of Congress]], the killing of seals was strictly regulated on the Pribiloff islands and in "the waters adjacent thereto". Beginning in about 1886, it became the practice of certain British and Canadian vessels to intercept passing seals in the open ocean (over three miles from any shore) and shoot them in the water (pelagic sealing).<ref name=nie>{{Cite NIE|wstitle=Sealing}}</ref> In the summer of 1886, three British Columbian sealers, the ''Carolena'', ''Onward'', and ''Thornton'', were captured by an American revenue cutter, the [[USRC Thomas Corwin (1876)|''Corwin'']],<ref>[http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3724963 ''British Columbia: From the Earliest Times to the Present, Vol .2, Chapter XXVII "The Sealing Industry and the Behring Sea Arbitration"''] E.O.S. Scholefield and F.W. Howay, S.J. Clarke Publ. Co, Vancouver, 1914, p. 461.</ref> The United States claimed exclusive jurisdiction over the sealing industry in the [[Bering Sea]]; it also contended that the protection of the [[fur seal]] was an international duty, and should be secured by international arrangement. The British imperial government repudiated the claim, but was willing to negotiate on the question of international regulation.
[[File:Hülgevaatlus, postipaat Helge.JPG|thumb|left|While people living in Estonian coastal areas used to hunt seals, this has changed a lot within the last half century. Within the last decade [[ecotourism]] has also emerged, and nowadays seal watching tours are being organized.]] The issue was taken to arbitration, which concluded in favour of Britain on all points in 1893. Since the decision was in favor of Great Britain, in accordance with the arbitration treaty the tribunal prescribed a series of regulations for preserving the seal herds which were to be binding upon and enforced by both powers. They limited pelagic sealing as to time, place, and manner by fixing a zone of 60 miles around the Pribilof Islands within which the seals were not to be molested at any time, and from May 1 to July 31 each year they were not to be pursued anywhere in Bering Sea. Only licensed sailing vessels were permitted to engage in fur sealing, and the use of firearms or explosives was prohibited.
This marked the first attempt at establishing regulations on the sealing industry for environmental purposes.<ref name=nie/> However, these regulations failed because the mother seals fed outside the protected area and remained vulnerable.<ref name=ea>{{Americana|wstitle=Seals and Sealing|author=George Archibald Clark|inline=1}}</ref> A joint commission of scientists from Britain and the United States further considered the problem, and came to the conclusion that the pelagic sealing needed to be curtailed. However further joint tribunals did not enact new legal restrictions, and then Japan also embarked upon pelagic sealing.<ref name=ea/>
Finally, the [[North Pacific Fur Seal Convention of 1911|North Pacific Fur Seal Convention]] severely curtailed the sealing industry. Signed on July 7, 1911 by the United States, [[Great Britain]], Japan, and Russia, the treaty was designed to manage the commercial harvest of fur bearing mammals. It outlawed open-water seal hunting and acknowledged the United States' [[jurisdiction]] in managing the on-shore hunting of seals for commercial purposes. It was the first international treaty to address wildlife preservation issues.<ref name="NOAA">{{cite web|url=http://celebrating200years.noaa.gov/events/fursealtreaty/welcome.html#treaty|title=North Pacific Fur Seal Treaty of 1911|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]}}</ref>
The treaty was dissolved with the onset of hostilities between the signatories in [[World War II]]. However, the treaty set precedent for future national and [[international laws]] and treaties, including the [[Fur Seal Act of 1966]] and the [[Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972]].<ref name="NOAA"/><ref name="NOAA"/>
Today, commercial sealing is conducted by only five nations: Canada, Greenland, Namibia, Norway, and Russia. The United States, which had been heavily involved in the sealing industry, now maintains a complete ban on the commercial hunting of marine mammals, with the exception of indigenous peoples who are allowed to hunt a small number of seals each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seashepherd.org/editorials/editorial_031217_1.html |title=Joe, What You Say Just Ain't So |publisher=Sea Shepherd |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref>
==Equipment and method== [[File:Hakapik.jpg|thumb|left|A ''[[hakapik]]'']]
In the Canadian commercial seal hunt, the majority of the hunters initiate the kill using a firearm. Ninety percent of sealers on the ice floes of the Front (east of Newfoundland), where the majority of non-native seal hunting occurs, use firearms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sealsandsealing.net/welfare.php?page=3&id=1 |publisher=Seals and Sealing Network|title= Animal Welfare in Canada |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref>
An older and more traditional method of killing seals is with a ''[[hakapik]]'': a heavy wooden club with a hammer head and metal hook on the end. The ''hakapik'' is used because of its efficiency; the animal can be killed quickly without damage to its pelt. The hammer head is used to crush the seals' thin skulls, while the hook is used to move the carcasses. Canadian sealing regulations describe the dimensions of the clubs and the ''[[hakapik]]s'', and caliber of the rifles and minimum bullet velocity, that can be used. They state: "Every person who strikes a seal with a club or hakapik shall strike the seal on the forehead until its skull has been crushed," and that "No person shall commence to skin or bleed a seal until the seal is dead," which occurs when it "has a glassy-eyed, staring appearance and exhibits no blinking reflex when its eye is touched while it is in a relaxed condition."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canlii.org/ca/regu/sor93-56/ |title=Marine Mammal Regulations, SOR/93-56 |publisher=Canadian Legal Information Institute |accessdate=2009-05-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706160525/http://www.canlii.org/ca/regu/sor93-56/ |archivedate=2008-07-06 |df= }}</ref> Reportedly, in one study, three out of eight times, the animal was not rendered either dead or unconscious by shooting, and the hunters would then kill the seal using a hakapik or other club of a type that is sanctioned by the governing authority.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/efsajournal/pub/610|title=Animal Welfare aspects of the killing and skinning of seals – Scientific Opinion of the Panel on Animal Health and Welfare |date=2007-12-19 |work= |publisher=European Food Safety Authority |journal=EFSA Journal |accessdate=2010-08-20 |doi=10.2903/j.efsa.2007.610 | }} [https://efsa.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.2903/j.efsa.2007.610 PDF file]</ref>
==Modern sealing== ===Products made from seals=== [[File:Selskinnsvest.JPG|thumb|upright|A [[waistcoat]] made of seal fur]] [[File:Phoeca groenlandica piece of meat upernavik 2007-06-26.JPG|thumb|left|Meat from a young [[harp seal]]]]
Seal skins have been used by aboriginal people for millennia to make waterproof jackets and boots, and seal fur to make fur coats. Pelts account for over half the processed value of a seal, selling at over C$100 each as of 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2006/04/19/nf-seal-pelt-20060419.html |title=Seal pelts fetch record prices |publisher=CBC News |date=2006-04-19 |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref> According to [[Paul Christian Rieber]], of [[GC Rieber AS]], the difficult ice conditions and low quotas in 2006 resulted in less access to seal pelts, which caused the commodity price to be pushed up.<ref name="rieberskinn">{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.no/na24/article408640.ece|title=Kjøligere for Rieber Skinn|language=Norwegian|work=Bergens Tidende|date=2007-09-12}}</ref> One high-end fashion designer, [[Donatella Versace]], has begun to use seal pelts, while others, such as [[Calvin Klein]], [[Stella McCartney]], [[Tommy Hilfiger]], and [[Ralph Lauren]], refrain from using any kind of fur.<ref name=wspa>{{cite web|url=http://www.savecanadianseals.org/companies.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928214633/http://www.savecanadianseals.org/companies.html|archivedate=2007-09-28|publisher=World Society for the Protection of Animal|title= Companies That Sell Seal Products|work=Save Canadian Seals}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=Independent Online |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?from=rss_News&set_id=1&click_id=79&art_id=nw20071002160158869C509823 |title=(Fur)shion show without clothes |work=IOL News |date=2007-10-02 |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref>
Seal meat is an important source of food for residents of small coastal communities.<ref name=portalcity>{{cite web|url=http://theportcitypost.com/2009/06/11/canadian-seal-hunt-attacked-by-peta/ |title=Canadian Seal Hunt Attacked by PETA |publisher=The Port City Post |date=2009-06-11 |accessdate=2011-07-24 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Meat is sold to the Asian pet food market; in 2004, only Taiwan and South Korea purchased seal meat from Canada.<ref name=seashepherd-facts>{{cite web|url=http://www.seashepherd.org/seals/seals_seal_hunt_facts.html|title=Seal Hunt Facts|work=Sea Shepherd|publisher=Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|accessdate=2011-07-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011043206/http://seashepherd.org/seals/seals_seal_hunt_facts.html|archivedate=2008-10-11|df=}}</ref> The seal blubber is used to make seal oil, which is marketed as a fish oil supplement. In 2001, two percent of Canada's raw seal oil was processed and sold in Canadian health stores.<ref name="regj"/> There has been virtually no market for seal organs since 1998.<ref name=portalcity />
===Sealing states=== In 2005, three companies exported seal skin: [[GC Rieber|Rieber]] in Norway, Atlantic Marine in Canada and Great Greenland in Greenland.<ref name=igjen>{{cite web|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article1030850.ece |title=Sel skinn selger igjen|language=Norwegian|work=Aftenposten|date=2005-05-02|accessdate=2008-05-06}}</ref> Their clients were earlier French fashion houses and fur makers in Europe, but today the fur is mainly exported to Russia and China.<ref name=igjen/>
====Canada==== In Canada, the season for the commercial hunt of [[harp seal]] is from November 15 to May 15.<ref name="Canada0305">{{cite web|url=http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/seal-phoque/reports-rapports/mgtplan-plangest2003/mgtplan-plangest2003_e.htm|archivedate=2008-06-20|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080620053344/http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/seal-phoque/reports-rapports/mgtplan-plangest2003/mgtplan-plangest2003_e.htm|title=Seals and Sealing in Canada|publisher=Fisheries and Aquaculture Management Canada}}</ref> While Inuit hunt seals commercially year-round, most sealing in southern Canada occurs in late March in the [[Gulf of St. Lawrence]], and during the first or second week of April off Newfoundland, in an area known as the Front. This peak spring period is often mistakenly referred to as the "Canadian Seal Hunt", when in fact seal hunting also happens throughout the year all over the Canadian Arctic.<ref name=faq-canada />
In 2003, the three-year harp seal quota granted by Fisheries and Oceans Canada was increased to a maximum of 975,000 animals per three years, with a maximum of 350,000 animals in any two consecutive years.<ref name = "Canada0305" /> In 2006, 325,000 harp seals, as well as 10,000 hooded seals and 10,400 [[grey seal]]s were killed. An additional 10,000 animals were allocated for hunting by aboriginal peoples. As of 2012, the population in Canada of the Northwest Atlantic harp seals is approximately 7.3 million animals, over three times what it was in the 1970s.<ref name="dfo-mpo.gc.ca">http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/fm-gp/seal-phoque/facts-faits/facts-faitsb-eng.htm</ref>
Although around 70% of Canadian seals killed are taken on the Front,<ref name = "faq-canada" /> private monitors focus on the St. Lawrence hunt, because of its more convenient location.<ref name="pmid12240525"/> The 2006 St. Lawrence leg of the hunt was officially closed on Apr. 3, 2006; sealers had already exceeded the quota by 1,000 animals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/04/03/seal-quota060403.html |title=Seal hunt haul 1,000 over quota|publisher= CBC News|date=2006-04-03 |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref> On March 26, 2007, the Newfoundland and Labrador government launched a seal hunt website to counter "misinformation about the sealing industry that is [published] by international animal rights organizations".<ref>[[Wikinews:Newfoundland government launches seal hunt website]]</ref>
Warm winters in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence have led to thinner and more unstable ice there. In 2007, Canada's [[Fisheries and Oceans Canada|federal fisheries ministry]] reported that while the pups are born on the ice as usual, the ice floes have started to break up before the pups learn to swim, causing the pups to drown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17736236/ |title=Seal hunt might be on ice due to lack of it |publisher=MSNBC |date=2007-03-27 |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref> Canada reduced the 2007 quota by 20%, because overflights showed large numbers of seal pups were lost to thin and melting ice.<ref name="Washington">{{cite news|title= Warming Thins Herd for Canada's Seal Hunt|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/03/AR2007040301754.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=2007-04-04 |accessdate=2008-02-18 | first=Doug | last=Struck}}</ref> In southern [[Labrador]] and off Newfoundland's northeast coast, however, there was extra heavy ice in 2007, and the coast guard estimated as many as 100 vessels were trapped in ice simultaneously.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2007/04/13/seals-ice.html |title=Heavy ice keeps dozens of vessels from seal hunt |publisher=CBC News |date=2007-04-13 |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/04/19/america/NA-GEN-Canada-Seal-Hunt-Evacuation.php |title=Canadian seal hunters could remain trapped by ice for a week: coast guard |newspaper=International Herald Tribune |date=2009-03-29 |accessdate=2009-05-07|agency=Associated Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070910032931/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/04/19/america/NA-GEN-Canada-Seal-Hunt-Evacuation.php|archivedate=2007-09-10}}</ref>
The 2010 hunt was cut short because demand for seal pelts was down. Only one local pelt buyer, NuTan Furs, offered to purchase pelts; and it committed to purchase less than 15,000 pelts.<ref>{{cite news|first=Michel|last=Comte |url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/canadas-seal-hunt-to-close-early-after-low-harvest-20100415-sh9q.html |title=Canada's seal hunt to close early after low harvest |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=2010-04-15 |accessdate=2010-05-02}}</ref> Pelt prices were about C$21/pelt in 2010, which is about twice the 2009 price and about 64% of the 2007 price. The reduced demand is attributable mainly to the 2009 ban on imports of seal products into the European Union.
The 2010 winter was unusually warm, with little ice forming in the Gulf of St. Lawrence in February and March, when harp seals give birth to their pups on ice floes. Around the Gulf, harp seals arrived in late winter to give birth on near-shore ice and even on beaches rather than on their usual whelping grounds: sturdy sea ice. Also, seal pups born elsewhere began floating to shore on small, shrinking pieces of ice. Many others stayed too far north, out of reach of all but the most determined hunters. Environment Canada, the weather forecasting agency, reported the ice was at the lowest level on record.<ref name=Austen>{{cite news|title=Despite Few Hunters, Seal Pups Face Threats|first=Ian |last=Austen|date=2010-04-01|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/02/world/americas/02seal.html?_r=0}}</ref>
=====Regulations===== The Fisheries Act established "Seal Protection Regulations" in the mid-1960s. The regulations were combined with other Canadian [[marine mammal]]s regulations in 1993, to form the "[[Marine Mammal Regulations]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fishaq.gov.nl.ca/sealfactsheet/history.htm|title=Seal Industry|publisher=[[Government of Newfoundland and Labrador]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327110242/http://www.fishaq.gov.nl.ca/sealfactsheet/history.htm|archivedate=2009-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/seal-phoque/reports-rapports/facts-faits/facts-faits_regs_e.htm|publisher=[[Fisheries and Oceans Canada]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080619034239/http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/seal-phoque/reports-rapports/facts-faits/facts-faits_regs_e.htm|archivedate=2008-06-19|title=Improvements to Seal Hunt Management Measures}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=K.|last= Ronald|first2= D.M.|last2= Lavigne |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/sealing/ |title=Sealing |publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia |date=1967-07-24 |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref> In addition to describing the use of the rifle and ''hakapik'', the regulations state every person "who fishes for seals for personal or commercial use shall land the [[Fur|pelt]] or the carcass of the seal."<ref name="pmid12240525"/> The commercial hunting of infant harp seals ([[whitecoats]]) and infant hooded seals (bluebacks) was banned in 1987 under pressure from animal rights groups. Now, seals may only be killed once they have started [[molting]] (from 12 to 15 days of age), as this coincides with the time when they are abandoned by their mothers.
=====Export===== Canada's biggest market for seal pelts is Norway.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2006/09/06/seal-hunt-eu.html |title=EU politicians push to ban Canadian seal product imports |accessdate=2007-10-24 | publisher=CBC News | date=2006-09-06}}</ref> Carino Limited is one of Newfoundland's largest seal pelt producers. Carino (CAnada–RIeber–NOrway) is marketing its seal pelts mainly through its parent company, [[GC Rieber Skinn]], [[Bergen, Norway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fishaq.gov.nl.ca/research_development/fdp/fdp_248.pdf |title=Secondary Processing of Seal Skins |year=2002 |publisher=Fisheries Diversification Program 248 |accessdate=2011-08-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001201822/http://www.fishaq.gov.nl.ca/research_development/fdp/fdp_248.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-01 |df= }}</ref> Canada sold pelts to eleven countries in 2004. The next largest were Germany, Greenland, and China/[[Hong Kong]]. Other importers were Finland, Denmark, France, Greece, South Korea, and Russia.<ref name=seashepherd-facts/> Asia remains the principal market for seal meat exports.<ref name=Canada0305 /> One of Canada's market access priorities for 2002 was to "continue to press Korean authorities to obtain the necessary approvals for the sale of seal meat for human consumption in Korea."<ref name=openingdoors>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sice.oas.org/geograph/mktacc/canada.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114080306/http://www.sice.oas.org/geograph/mktacc/canada.pdf|archivedate=2006-11-14|title=Opening Doors to the World|publisher=Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade|journal=Canada's International Market Access Priorities – 2002}}</ref> Canadian and Korean officials agreed in 2003 on specific Korean import requirements for seal meat.<ref name=openingdoors /> For 2004, only Taiwan and South Korea purchased seal meat from Canada.<ref name=seashepherd-facts />
Canadian seal product exports reached C$18 million in 2006. Of this, C$5.4 million went to the EU.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ies.ubc.ca/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=152&Itemid=198 |title=The Institute for European Studies |publisher=University of British Columbia |date=2008-08-29 |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref> In 2009, the European Union banned all seal imports, shrinking the market.<ref>{{cite web|author = European Parliament | authorlink = European Parliament | title = MEPs adopt strict conditions for the placing on the market of seal products in the European Union | work = Hearings | date = 2009-11-09| url = http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//TEXT+IM-PRESS+20090504IPR54952+0+DOC+XML+V0//EN | accessdate =2010-03-12}}</ref> Where pelts once sold for more than $100, they now fetch $8 to $15 each.<ref name=Austen/>
====Denmark==== =====Greenland===== Although the government of Greenland states that approximately 170,000 seals are killed in Greenland annually,<ref name="nanook">{{cite web|title=Resources and Industry |publisher=Government of Greenland |url=http://uk.nanoq.gl/Emner/About/Resources_and_industry.aspx |accessdate=2012-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223085319/http://uk.nanoq.gl/Emner/About/Resources_and_industry.aspx |archivedate=2012-02-23 |df= }}</ref> the Government of Canada estimates the kill to be 20,000 to 25,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/zone/underwater_sous-marin/hseal/seal-phoque_e.htm |title=The Harp Seal |publisher=Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060207145022/http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/zone/underwater_sous-marin/hseal/seal-phoque_e.htm |archivedate=February 7, 2006 }}</ref> In January 2006, the government of Greenland banned imports of Canadian seal skins, citing fears Canadian seals are brutally beaten to death. The boycott may be an effort to distance Greenland's own seal hunt from Canada's, and spare themselves negative press in the process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20060109-100956-1841r|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516165809/http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Top_News/2006/01/09/greenland_bans_canadian_sealskins/1841/|archivedate=2008-05-16 |title=Greenland bans Canadian sealskins |publisher=United Press International |date=2011-02-27 |accessdate=2011-03-03}}</ref> The ban was rescinded in May 2006, with the Greenland Home Rule Government noting the seal hunt in Canada has sensible regulations on hunting methods, drawn up in close cooperation with biologists, veterinarians, weapons experts and seal hunters.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} It further noted seal-hunting in Canada is subject to strict and extensive control measures, to ensure the use of effective and humane killing methods.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}
In Greenland, seal hunting is conducted with rifles – the seals are shot in the head from a small open boat while they sit on an ice floe. The boat rushes up to the seal and hooks the carcass out of the water (where it falls within a few seconds) before it sinks. The economy of certain rural Greenlandic villages, such as [[Aappilattoq, Kujalleq|Aappilattoq]], are highly dependent upon such seal hunting.<ref>{{cite book|last=O'Carroll|first=Etain|title=Greenland & the Arctic|year=2005|publisher=Lonely Planet|location=Footscray, Victoria|isbn=9781740590952|edition=2nd}}</ref>

Namibia is the only country in the [[Southern Hemisphere]] culling seals. Although the protection and the sustainable use of natural resources is part of Namibia's constitution, it claims to conduct the second largest seal harvest in the world,<ref name="nam2006"/> mainly because of the huge amount of fish seals are estimated to consume. While a government-initiated study found seal colonies consume more fish than the entire fishing industry can catch,<ref name="nam2007"/> animal protection society Seal Alert South Africa estimated less than 0.3% losses to commercial fisheries.<ref name="nam2010-2"/>
Harvesting is done from July to November<ref name="nam2010-2"/> on two places, [[Cape Cross]] and [[Atlas Bay]], and in the past at [[Wolf Bay]].<ref name="nam2007"/> These two colonies together account for 75% of the [[brown fur seal|cape fur seal]] population of the country.<ref name="nam2006"/>
[[Cape Cross Seal Reserve|Cape Cross]] is a tourism resort and the largest cape fur colony in Namibia. The Department of Tourism has stated<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.gov.na/Documents/Cape%20Cross%20National%20Park.pdf|title=Cape Cross National Park|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927064907/http://www.met.gov.na/Documents/Cape%20Cross%20National%20Park.pdf|archivedate=2011-09-27|df=}}</ref> that "Cape Cross Seal Reserve was established to protect the largest breeding colony of Cape fur seals in the world". In season, the resort is closed and sealed off during the culling in the early morning hours, journalists are not allowed to enter.<ref name="nam2009"/> Namibia’s [[Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|SPCA]] is allowed to observe the culling from 2010 onwards.<ref name="nam2010"/>
Namibia's Ministry of Fisheries announced a three-year rolling quota for the seal harvest, although different quotas per year are sometimes reported.<ref name="nam2007"/><ref name="nam2009"/> The {{As of|2010|alt=latest}} quota announced was in 2009, valid until 2011.<ref name="nam2010"/> The quotas are usually not filled by the concession holders.<ref name="nam2010-2"/>
In 2009, an unusual bid to end seal culling in Namibia was attempted when Seal Alert tried to raise money to purchase the only buyer of Namibian seals, Australian-based Hatem Yavuz, [[lock, stock, and barrel]] for US$14.2 million.<ref name="nam2009"/> The project did not materialise. Also, the Government of Namibia offered the [[International Fund for Animal Welfare]] (IFAW) an opportunity to buy out the two sealers in Namibia to finally end the culling. The offer was rejected.<ref name="nam2006"/>
In 2011, South African activists launched a boycott of Namibian tourism and Namibian products<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/thesealsofnam/get-involved/the-boycott|title=The Boycott|work=The Seals of Nam}}{{self-published inline|date=December 2012}}</ref> in response to the cull.

[[File:Hakapik x 2.jpg|left|thumb|''[[Hakapik]]s'' displayed on the wall of a gun shop in [[Tromsø]], Norway]] [[File:Seal hunting on ice in 1904.jpg|thumb|left|Seal hunting on ice in 1904]] [[File:Sealing vessel "Havsel".jpg|thumb|left|The Norwegian sealing vessel ''Havsel'' in the [[West Ice]] in 2017]] The Norwegian sealing season runs from January to September. The hunt involves "seal catching" by seagoing sealing boats on the Arctic [[ice shelf]], and "seal hunting" on the coast and islands of mainland Norway. The latter is carried out by small groups of licensed hunters shooting seals from land and using small boats to retrieve the catch.
In 2005, Norway allowed foreign nationals to take part in the hunt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://odin.dep.no/fkd/english/news/news/047041-990012/dok-bn.html |title=Fact sheet on Norwegian coastal seals |publisher=Fiskeri- og kystdepartementet|accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref> In 2006, 17,037 seals (including 13,390 harp and 3,647 hooded seals) were harvested.<ref name=stat /> In 2007, the [[Norwegian Ministry of Fisheries and Coastal Affairs]] stated up to 13.5 million [[Norwegian krone]] (about US$2.6 million) would be given in funding to vessels in the 2007 Norwegian seal hunt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.regjeringen.no/nb/dep/fkd/aktuelt/Nyheter/2007/Selfangsten-i-2007-.html?id=455371 |title=Selfangsten i 2007|publisher= [[Government of Norway]]|date=2007-02-27|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
=====Regulations===== All Norwegian sealing vessels are required to carry a qualified veterinary inspector on board.<ref name="norwegianembassy">{{cite web|author=the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs |url=http://www.norway.org/policy/environment/sealing/sealing.htm |title=Norwegian Sealing |publisher=Norwegian Embassy in the United States|date=2009-04-03 |accessdate=2009-05-07 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080319075512/http://www.norway.org/policy/environment/sealing/sealing.htm |archivedate =2008-03-19}}</ref> Norwegian sealers are required to pass a shooting test each year before the season starts, using the same weapon and ammunition as they would on the ice. Likewise, they have to pass a ''hakapik'' test.<ref name="Selfangstsforskrift">{{cite web|url=http://lovdata.no/for/sf/fi/ti-20030211-0151-0.html#1 |title=Forskrift om utøvelse av selfangst i Vesterisen og Østisen |publisher=Lovdata|date=2003-02-11 |accessdate=2009-05-07|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
Adult seals more than one year old must be shot in the head with expanding bullets, and cannot be clubbed to death. The ''hakapik'' shall be used to ensure the animal is dead. This is done by crushing the skull of the shot adult seal with the short end of the ''hakapik'', before the long spike is thrust deep into the animal's brain. The seal is then bled by making an incision from its jaw to the end of its [[sternum]]. The killing and bleeding must be done on the ice, and live animals may never be brought on board the ship. Young seals may be killed using just the ''hakapik'', but only in the aforementioned manner, i.e., they need not be shot.<ref name="Selfangstsforskrift"/>
Seals in the water and seals with young may not be killed, and the use of traps, artificial lighting, airplanes, or helicopters is forbidden.<ref name="Selfangstsforskrift"/>
The ''hakapik'' may only be used by certified seal-catchers (fangstmenn) operating in the [[pack ice]] of the [[Arctic Ocean]] and not by coastal seal hunters. All coastal seal hunters must be pre-approved by the [[Norwegian Directorate of Fisheries]] and have to pass a large game hunting test.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lovdata.no/cgi-wift/ldles?doc=/sf/sf/sf-19960506-0414.html#10 |title=For 1996-05-06 nr 414: Forskrift om forvaltning av sel på norskekysten |publisher=Lovdata|accessdate=2009-05-07}}{{dead link|date=December 2012}}</ref>
In 2007, the European Food Safety Agency confirmed the animals are put to death faster and more humanely in the Norwegian sealing than in large game hunting on land.<ref name="norwegianembassy"/>
=====Export===== In Norway in 2004, only [[GC Rieber|Rieber]] worked with sealskin and seal oil.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.fiskerifond.no/files/news/attach/selolje1.pdf |title=Utviklingsplan for selspekk |publisher=Fiskeri- og havbruksnæringens forskningsfond (FHF) |date=February 2004 |last=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411094210/http://www.fiskerifond.no/files/news/attach/selolje1.pdf |archivedate=April 11, 2008 }}</ref> In 2001, the biggest producer of raw seal oil was Canada (two percent of the raw oil was processed and sold in Canadian health stores).<ref name="regj"/> Rieber had the majority of all distribution of raw seal oil in the world market, but there was no demand for seal oil.<ref name="regj">{{cite tiltak|publisher=[[Government of Norway]]|date=March 2001|language=Norwegian}}</ref> From 1995 to 2005, Rieber annually received between 2 and 3 million [[Norwegian krone]] in subsidy.<ref>{{cite parliamentary report says [[CG Rieber Skinn]] is the only company in the world that delivers skin from [[hooded seal|bluebacks]].<ref>{{cite
